/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1.title: Purposes
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1.content:
The main purposes of this Act are— 
 (a) to create a legislative framework to give 
effect to the objects of this Act; and 
 (b) to repeal the Occupational Health and 
Safety Act 1985; and 
 (c) to provide for matters of a transitional nature 
and make consequential amendments.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1/a.content: to create a legislative framework to give The main purposes of this Act are— effect to the objects of this Act; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1/b.content: to repeal the Occupational Health and Safety Act 1985; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1/c.content: to provide for matters of a transitional nature and make consequential amendments.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2.title: Objects
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
2   
 (d) to provide for the involvement of employees, 
employers, and organisations representing 
those persons, in the formulation and 
implementation of health, safety and welfare 
standards— 
having regard to the principles of health and 
safety protection set out in section 4. 
 (2) It is the intention of the Parliament that in the 
administration of this Act regard should be had to 
the principles of health and safety protection set 
out in section 4.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2/1.content: The objects of this Act are—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2/1/a.content: to secure the health, safety and welfare of employees and other persons at work; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2/1/b.content: to eliminate, at the source, risks to the health, safety or welfare of employees and other persons at work; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2/1/c.content: to ensure that the health and safety of members of the public is not placed at risk by the conduct of undertakings by employers and self-employed persons; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2/d.content: to provide for the involvement of employees, Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 2 employers, and organisations representing those persons, in the formulation and implementation of health, safety and welfare standards— having regard to the principles of health and safety protection set out in section 4.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2/2.content: It is the intention of the Parliament that in the administration of this Act regard should be had to the principles of health and safety protection set out in section 4.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s3.title: Commencement
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s3.content:
(1) Subject to this section, this Act comes into 
operation on 1 July 2005. 
 (2) Section 28 comes into operation on 1 July 2006. 
 (3) Division 6 of Part 2 and section 172(2) come into 
operation on the day after the day on which this 
Act receives the Royal Assent. 
 (4) Part 4 comes into operation on a day to be 
proclaimed but if it has not come into operation 
before 1 January 2006, it comes into operation on 
that day.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s3/1.content: Subject to this section, this Act comes into operation on 1 July 2005.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s3/2.content: Section 28 comes into operation on 1 July 2006.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s3/3.content: Division 6 of Part 2 and section 172(2) come into operation on the day after the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s3/4.content: Part 4 comes into operation on a day to be proclaimed but if it has not come into operation before 1 January 2006, it comes into operation on that day.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s4.title: The principles of health and safety protection
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s4.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
3   
 (3) Employers and self-employed persons should be 
proactive, and take all reasonably practicable 
measures, to ensure health and safety at 
workplaces and in the conduct of undertakings. 
 (4) Employers and employees should exchange 
information and ideas about risks to health and 
safety and measures that can be taken to eliminate 
or reduce those risks. 
 (5) Employees are entitled, and should be 
encouraged, to be represented in relation to health 
and safety issues.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s4/1.content: The importance of health and safety requires that employees, other persons at work and members of the public be given the highest level of protection against risks to their health and safety that is reasonably practicable in the circumstances.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s4/2.content: Persons who control or manage matters that give rise or may give rise to risks to health or safety are responsible for eliminating or reducing those risks so far as is reasonably practicable.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s4/3.content: Employers and self-employed persons should be Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 3 proactive, and take all reasonably practicable measures, to ensure health and safety at workplaces and in the conduct of undertakings.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s4/4.content: Employers and employees should exchange information and ideas about risks to health and safety and measures that can be taken to eliminate or reduce those risks.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s4/5.content: Employees are entitled, and should be encouraged, to be represented in relation to health and safety issues.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s6/1.content: This Act and the regulations bind the Crown—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s6/1/a.content: in right of the State of Victoria; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s6/1/b.content: to the extent that the legislative power of the Parliament permits, in all its other capacities.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7.title: Functions of the Authority
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
13   
 (5) The Authority must ensure, as far as possible, that 
information it gives is in a form and in such 
languages as is appropriate for the persons to 
whom it is directed.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/1.content: The Authority has the following functions—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/1/a.content: to enquire into and report to the Minister on any matters referred to the Authority by the Minister (within the time specified by the Minister);

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/1/b.content: to make recommendations to the Minister with respect to— (i) the operation and administration of this Act and the regulations; and (ii) regulations or compliance codes that the Minister or the Authority proposes should be made or approved under this Act; and (iii) the establishment of public inquiries (if appropriate) into any matter relating to occupational health, safety and welfare;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/1/c.content: to monitor and enforce compliance with this Act and the regulations;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/1/d.content: to administer, examine, review and make recommendations concerning existing or proposed registration or licensing schemes relating to occupational health, safety and welfare;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/1/e.content: to co-operate with, and give advice and information to the following persons in relation to occupational health, safety and welfare—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/f.content: to disseminate information about the duties, Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 11 (i) corresponding Authorities; (ii) registered employee organisations (within the meaning of Part 8) and other organisations representing employers or employees; (iii) other interested persons; obligations and rights of persons under this Act or the regulations and to formulate standards, specifications or other forms of guidance for the purpose of assisting persons to comply with their duties and obligations;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/g.content: to promote education and training by— (i) devising, in co-operation with educational and other bodies, courses in occupational health, safety and welfare; and (ii) approving courses in occupational health, safety and welfare (whether or not devised in co-operation with another body); and (iii) facilitating access to those courses; and (iv) initiating or promoting events such as conferences and forums, and the publication of information, relating to occupational health, safety and welfare;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/h.content: to foster a co-operative, consultative relationship between employers and their employees in relation to the health, safety and welfare of those employees; (i) to engage in, promote and co-ordinate the sharing of information to achieve the objects of this Act;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/j.content: to promote public awareness and discussion Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 12 of occupational health, safety and welfare issues and an understanding and acceptance of the principles of health and safety protection set out in section 4;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/k.content: to develop and implement programs to provide incentives for employers— (i) to implement measures to eliminate or reduce risks to health or safety; and (ii) to otherwise improve occupational health, safety and welfare;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/l.content: to monitor the operation of measures taken and arrangements put in place to ensure occupational health, safety and welfare;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/m.content: to initiate and encourage research to identify efficient and effective strategies for improving occupational health, safety and welfare;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/n.content: to collect and publish statistics relating to occupational health, safety and welfare. Note The Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013 also confers functions on the Authority relating to occupational health, safety and welfare.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/2.content: The Authority also has such other functions as are conferred on it by or under this Act.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/3.content: Before the Authority makes a recommendation to the Minister under subsection (1)(b)(ii) concerning a proposed compliance code, it must issue the proposed compliance code for public review and comment.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/4.content: However, the Authority need not comply with subsection (3) if the Minister considers that it is in the public interest that the proposed compliance code be made as soon as practicable. Note to s. 7(1) amended by No. 67/2013 s. 649(Sch. 9 item 25(2)).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s7/5.content: The Authority must ensure, as far as possible, that Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 13 information it gives is in a form and in such languages as is appropriate for the persons to whom it is directed.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8/1.content: Subject to this Act, the Authority has the power to do all things necessary or convenient to be done for or in connection with the performance of its functions.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8/2.content: Without limiting subsection (1), the Authority has all the functions and powers that an inspector has under this Act or the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8/3.content: Without limiting subsection (1), the Authority has the following powers—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8/3/a.content: the power to enter into agreements or contracts with a corresponding Authority for or with respect to the following— (i) the Authority performing the functions or exercising the powers of the corresponding Authority as its agent; (ii) the Authority performing works or providing services for the corresponding Authority; (iii) the Authority giving information to the corresponding Authority; (iv) the Authority providing the corresponding Authority with the use of its facilities or the services of its staff; (v) the corresponding Authority doing any of the things in subparagraphs (i) to (iv) for or in respect of the Authority;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8/b.content: in addition to, but not limited by, any other Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 14 power under this section, the power to provide related and ancillary services. Note For corresponding Authority, see section 5.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8AA.title: Use of information
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8AA.content:
(1) Information collected by the Authority under this 
Act or the regulations may be used by the 
Authority to perform its functions and exercise its 
powers under any Act if the use— 
 (a) is reasonably necessary for the purposes of 
performing a function or exercising a power 
conferred on the Authority under that Act or 
regulations made under that Act; or 
 (b) is directly related to a function or power 
conferred on the Authority under that Act. 
 (2) This section does not affect the operation of— 
 (a) the Health Records Act 2001; or 
 (b) the Privacy and Data Protection Act 2014; 
or 
 (c) the Victorian Data Sharing Act 2017.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8AA/1.content: Information collected by the Authority under this Act or the regulations may be used by the Authority to perform its functions and exercise its powers under any Act if the use—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8AA/1/a.content: is reasonably necessary for the purposes of performing a function or exercising a power conferred on the Authority under that Act or regulations made under that Act; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8AA/1/b.content: is directly related to a function or power conferred on the Authority under that Act.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8AA/2.content: This section does not affect the operation of—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s8AA/2/b.content: the Privacy and Data Protection Act 2014; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s12.title: Power to make guidelines
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s12.content:
(1) The Authority may, in accordance with this 
Division, make guidelines on the way in which— 
 (a) a provision of this Act or of a regulation 
made under this Act would, in the 
Authority's opinion, apply to a class of 
persons or to a set of circumstances; or 
 (b) a discretion of the Authority under a 
provision of, or regulation made under, this 
Act would be exercised. 
 (2) For the purposes of this section, the Authority 
exercises a discretion if the Authority— 
 (a) forms an opinion; or 
 (b) attains a state of mind; or 
 (c) makes a determination; or 
 (d) exercises a power; or 
 (e) refuses or fails to do any of those things.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s12/1/b.content: a discretion of the Authority under a provision of, or regulation made under, this Act would be exercised.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s12/2.content: For the purposes of this section, the Authority exercises a discretion if the Authority—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s12/2/b.content: attains a state of mind; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s12/2/e.content: refuses or fails to do any of those things.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s13/1/a.content: ensure notice of the proposed guidelines is published in the Government Gazette and a newspaper circulating generally throughout the State; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s13/1/b.content: include in the notice a statement that written submissions or comments on the proposed guidelines may be made to the Authority within a specified period; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s13/c.content: give a copy of the proposed guidelines to Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 19 each person who requests it during that period.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s13/2.content: After considering the submissions and comments (if any) received by the Authority within the specified period, the Authority may make the guidelines (with or without modifications) by causing notice of them to be published in the Government Gazette.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s13/3.content: If the Authority makes guidelines, it must ensure notice of them is also published in a newspaper circulating generally throughout the State.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s14.title: Withdrawal of guidelines
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s14.content:
(1) The Authority may withdraw guidelines by 
causing notice of the withdrawal to be published 
in the Government Gazette. 
 (2) The notice must also be published in a newspaper 
circulating generally throughout the State.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s14/1.content: The Authority may withdraw guidelines by causing notice of the withdrawal to be published in the Government Gazette.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s14/2.content: The notice must also be published in a newspaper circulating generally throughout the State.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s15.title: Guidelines do not affect rights and duties etc.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s15/a.content: any liability of, or other claim against, the Guidelines under this Division do not give rise to— Authority; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s15/b.content: any right, expectation, duty or obligation that would not otherwise be conferred or imposed on a person; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s15/c.content: any defence that would not otherwise be available to that person.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s16.title: Authority may accept undertakings
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s16.content:
(1) The Authority may accept (by written notice) a 
written undertaking given by a person in 
connection with a matter relating to a 
contravention or alleged contravention by the 
person of this Act or the regulations. 
 (2) The person may withdraw or vary the undertaking 
at any time but only with the Authority's written 
consent. 
 (3) A person who gives an undertaking under this 
section must not contravene the undertaking. 
Penalty: 500 penalty units for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s16/1.content: The Authority may accept (by written notice) a written undertaking given by a person in connection with a matter relating to a contravention or alleged contravention by the person of this Act or the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s16/2.content: The person may withdraw or vary the undertaking at any time but only with the Authority's written consent.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s16/3.content: A person who gives an undertaking under this section must not contravene the undertaking. Penalty: 500 penalty units for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2500.title: penalty units for a body corporate.
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2500.content:
(4) Neither the Authority nor an inspector may bring 
a proceeding for an offence against this Act or the 
regulations constituted by the contravention or 
alleged contravention to which an undertaking 
relates— 
 (a) while the undertaking is in effect; or 
 (b) if the undertaking has been fully complied 
with and discharged.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2500/4.content: Neither the Authority nor an inspector may bring a proceeding for an offence against this Act or the regulations constituted by the contravention or alleged contravention to which an undertaking relates—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2500/4/a.content: while the undertaking is in effect; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s2500/4/b.content: if the undertaking has been fully complied with and discharged.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s17.title: Enforcement of undertakings
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s17.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
21   
 (2) If the Magistrates' Court is satisfied that the 
person has contravened the undertaking, it may 
make— 
 (a) an order that the person must comply with 
the undertaking or take specified action to 
comply with the undertaking; or 
 (b) any other order that it considers appropriate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s17/1.content: If the Authority considers that a person has contravened an undertaking accepted by the Authority, the Authority may apply to the Magistrates' Court for enforcement of the undertaking. substituted by No. 48/2017 s. 10. inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 10.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s17/2.content: If the Magistrates' Court is satisfied that the Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 21 person has contravened the undertaking, it may make—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s17/2/a.content: an order that the person must comply with the undertaking or take specified action to comply with the undertaking; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s17/2/b.content: any other order that it considers appropriate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s18.title: Power to give advice on compliance

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s18/1.content: The Authority may give advice to a person who has a duty or obligation under this Act or the regulations about complying with that duty or obligation.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s18/2.content: The giving of such advice by the Authority does not give rise to—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s18/2/a.content: any liability of, or other claim against, the Authority; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s18/2/b.content: any right, expectation, duty or obligation that would not otherwise be conferred or imposed on the person given the advice; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s18/2/c.content: any defence that would not otherwise be available to that person.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s18/3.content: The Authority's power under this section to give advice may also be exercised by an inspector or, if the Authority authorises any other person to exercise the power, that other person. Note An inspector or other person exercising this power may not be liable for things done or omitted to be done in good faith (see section 499(3) of the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013). Note to s. 18(3) amended by No. 67/2013 s. 649(Sch. 9 item 25(3)).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/1.content: There is to be an Occupational Health and Safety Committee Advisory Committee.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/2.content: The Chairperson of the Authority's Board of Management, or such other member of the Board as the Chairperson nominates, is to be the Chairperson of the Occupational Health and Safety Advisory Committee.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/3.content: The Occupational Health and Safety Advisory Committee is to consist of the Chairperson and the following members appointed (in writing) by the Minister from time to time—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/3/a.content: 2 persons recommended by the Authority's Board of Management who represent the interests of the Authority;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/3/b.content: 2 persons who the Minister considers represent the interests of the Crown;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/3/c.content: 6 persons who the Minister considers represent the interests of employers (at least 2 of whom the Minister considers represent the interests of employers engaged in small business);

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/3/d.content: 6 persons who the Minister considers represent the interests of employees;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/3/e.content: 2 independent persons who the Minister considers have appropriate expertise and experience in occupational health and safety;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/3/f.content: 2 persons who the Minister considers have been affected, directly or indirectly, by a workplace incident that involves death or a serious injury or illness. amended by No. 27/2025 s. 56(a). inserted by No. 27/2025 s. 56(b).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/4.content: The functions of the Occupational Health and Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 23 Safety Advisory Committee are—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/4/a.content: to enquire into and report to the Authority's Board of Management on any matters referred to it by the Board in accordance with the terms of reference given by the Board; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/4/b.content: to advise the Board in relation to— (i) promoting healthy and safe working environments; and (ii) the operation and administration of this Act and the regulations; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/4/c.content: to carry out such other functions as are conferred by this Act.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s19/5.content: The Occupational Health and Safety Advisory Committee must operate in accordance with the procedures (if any) determined by the Authority's Board of Management.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s20.title: The concept of ensuring health and safety
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s20.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
25   
 (e) the cost of eliminating or reducing the hazard 
or risk.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s20/1.content: To avoid doubt, a duty imposed on a person by this Part or the regulations to ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, health and safety requires the person—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s20/1/a.content: to eliminate risks to health and safety so far as is reasonably practicable; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s20/1/b.content: if it is not reasonably practicable to eliminate risks to health and safety, to reduce those risks so far as is reasonably practicable.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s20/2.content: To avoid doubt, for the purposes of this Part and the regulations, regard must be had to the following matters in determining what is (or was at a particular time) reasonably practicable in relation to ensuring health and safety—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s20/2/a.content: the likelihood of the hazard or risk concerned eventuating;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s20/2/b.content: the degree of harm that would result if the hazard or risk eventuated;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s20/2/c.content: what the person concerned knows, or ought reasonably to know, about the hazard or risk and any ways of eliminating or reducing the hazard or risk;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s20/2/d.content: the availability and suitability of ways to eliminate or reduce the hazard or risk;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s20/e.content: the cost of eliminating or reducing the hazard Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 25 or risk.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21.title: Duties of employers to employees
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
26   
 (e) provide such information, instruction, 
training or supervision to employees of the 
employer as is necessary to enable those 
persons to perform their work in a way that 
is safe and without risks to health. 
 (3) For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2)— 
 (a) a reference to an employee includes a 
reference to an independent contractor 
engaged by an employer and any employees 
of the independent contractor; and 
 (b) the duties of an employer under those 
subsections extend to an independent 
contractor engaged by the employer, and any 
employees of the independent contractor, in 
relation to matters over which the employer 
has control or would have control if not for 
any agreement purporting to limit or remove 
that control. 
 (4) An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable 
offence. 
Note 
However, the offence may be heard and determined 
summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 
2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21/1.content: An employer must, so far as is reasonably practicable, provide and maintain for employees of the employer a working environment that is safe and without risks to health. Penalty: 1800 penalty units for a natural person; 9000 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21/2.content: Without limiting subsection (1), an employer contravenes that subsection if the employer fails to do any of the following—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21/2/a.content: provide or maintain plant or systems of work that are, so far as is reasonably practicable, safe and without risks to health;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21/2/b.content: make arrangements for ensuring, so far as is reasonably practicable, safety and the absence of risks to health in connection with the use, handling, storage or transport of plant or substances;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21/2/c.content: maintain, so far as is reasonably practicable, each workplace under the employer's management and control in a condition that is safe and without risks to health;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21/2/d.content: provide, so far as is reasonably practicable, adequate facilities for the welfare of employees at any workplace under the management and control of the employer;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21/e.content: provide such information, instruction, Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 26 training or supervision to employees of the employer as is necessary to enable those persons to perform their work in a way that is safe and without risks to health.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21/3.content: For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2)—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21/3/a.content: a reference to an employee includes a reference to an independent contractor engaged by an employer and any employees of the independent contractor; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21/3/b.content: the duties of an employer under those subsections extend to an independent contractor engaged by the employer, and any employees of the independent contractor, in relation to matters over which the employer has control or would have control if not for any agreement purporting to limit or remove that control.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s21/4.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

employer (in such other languages as

Penalty: 240 penalty units for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s22/c.content: provide information to employees of the Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 27 employer (in such other languages as appropriate) concerning health and safety at the workplace, including the names of persons to whom an employee may make an enquiry or complaint about health and safety. Penalty: 240 penalty units for a natural person; 1200 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s22/2.content: An employer must, so far as is reasonably practicable—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s22/2/a.content: keep information and records relating to the health and safety of employees of the employer; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s22/2/b.content: employ or engage persons who are suitably qualified in relation to occupational health and safety to provide advice to the employer concerning the health and safety of employees of the employer. Penalty: 60 penalty units for a natural person; 300 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s23/1.content: An employer must ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, that persons other than employees of the employer are not exposed to risks to their health or safety arising from the conduct of the undertaking of the employer. Penalty: 1800 penalty units for a natural person; 9000 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s23/2.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 28 offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s24.title: Duties of self-employed persons to other persons
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s24.content:
(1) A self-employed person must ensure, so far as is 
reasonably practicable, that persons are not 
exposed to risks to their health or safety arising 
from the conduct of the undertaking of the 
self-employed person. 
Penalty: 1800 penalty units.

offence. 
Note 
However, the offence may be heard and determined 
summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 
2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s24/1.content: A self-employed person must ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, that persons are not exposed to risks to their health or safety arising from the conduct of the undertaking of the self-employed person. Penalty: 1800 penalty units.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s24/2.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s25.title: Duties of employees
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s25.content:

29   
 (c) co-operate with his or her employer with 
respect to any action taken by the employer 
to comply with a requirement imposed by or 
under this Act or the regulations. 
Penalty: 1800 penalty units. 
 (2) While at work, an employee must not 
intentionally or recklessly interfere with or misuse 
anything provided at the workplace in the interests 
of health, safety or welfare. 
Penalty: 1800 penalty units. 
 (3) In determining for the purposes of subsection 
(1)(a) or (b) whether an employee failed to take 
reasonable care, regard must be had to what the 
employee knew about the relevant circumstances.

indictable offence.  
Note 
However, the offence may be heard and determined 
summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 
2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s25/1.content: While at work, an employee must—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s25/1/a.content: take reasonable care for his or her own health and safety; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s25/1/b.content: take reasonable care for the health and safety of persons who may be affected by the employee's acts or omissions at a workplace; and Note to s. 23(2) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.2). Note to s. 24(2) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.3).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s25/c.content: co-operate with his or her employer with Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 29 respect to any action taken by the employer to comply with a requirement imposed by or under this Act or the regulations. Penalty: 1800 penalty units.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s25/2.content: While at work, an employee must not intentionally or recklessly interfere with or misuse anything provided at the workplace in the interests of health, safety or welfare. Penalty: 1800 penalty units.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s25/3.content: In determining for the purposes of subsection (1)(a) or (b) whether an employee failed to take reasonable care, regard must be had to what the employee knew about the relevant circumstances.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s25/4.content: An offence against subsection (1) or (2) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 
2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s26/1.content: A person who (whether as an owner or otherwise) workplaces has, to any extent, the management or control of a workplace must ensure so far as is reasonably practicable that the workplace and the means of entering and leaving it are safe and without risks to health. Penalty: 1800 penalty units for a natural person; 9000 penalty units for a body corporate. Note to s. 25(4) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.4).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s26/2.content: The duties of a person under subsection (1) apply Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 30 only in relation to matters over which the person has management or control.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s26/3.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

No. 107 of 2004 
31   
 (d) on request, give such information to a person 
who uses or is to use the plant. 
Penalty: 1800 penalty units for a natural person; 
9000 penalty units for a body corporate. 
 (2) An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable 
offence.  
Note 
However, the offence may be heard and determined 
summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 
2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s27/1.content: A person who designs plant who knows, or ought reasonably to know, that the plant is to be used at a workplace must—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s27/1/a.content: ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, that it is designed to be safe and without risks to health if it is used for a purpose for which it was designed; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s27/1/b.content: carry out, or arrange the carrying out, of such testing and examination as may be necessary for the performance of the duty imposed by paragraph (a); and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s27/1/c.content: give adequate information to each person to whom the designer gives the design and who is to give effect to it concerning— (i) the purpose or purposes for which the plant was designed; and (ii) the results of any testing or examination referred to in paragraph (b); and (iii) any conditions necessary to ensure that the plant is safe and without risks to health if it is used for a purpose for which it was designed; and Note to s. 26(3) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.5).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s27/d.content: on request, give such information to a person Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 31 who uses or is to use the plant. Penalty: 1800 penalty units for a natural person; 9000 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s27/2.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s28.title: Duties of designers of buildings or structures
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s28.content:

32

Penalty: 500 penalty units for a natural person; 2500 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s28/2.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009). Note to s. 27(2) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.6). Note to s. 28(2) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.7).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s29/1.content: A person who manufactures plant or a substance who knows, or ought reasonably to know, that the plant or substance is to be used at a workplace must—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s29/1/a.content: ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, that it is manufactured to be safe and without risks to health if it is used for a purpose for which it was manufactured; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s29/1/b.content: carry out, or arrange the carrying out, of such testing and examination as may be necessary for the performance of the duty imposed by paragraph (a); and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s29/1/c.content: give adequate information to each person to whom the manufacturer provides the plant or substance concerning— (i) the purpose or purposes for which the plant or substance was manufactured; and (ii) the results of any testing or examination referred to in paragraph (b); and (iii) any conditions necessary to ensure that the plant or substance is safe and without risks to health if it is used for a purpose for which it was manufactured; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s29/1/d.content: on request, give such information to a person who uses or is to use the plant or substance. Penalty: 1800 penalty units for a natural person; 9000 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s29/2.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 33 offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s30/1.content: A person who supplies plant or a substance who knows, or ought reasonably to know, that the plant or substance is to be used at a workplace (whether by the person to whom it is supplied or anyone else) must—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s30/1/a.content: ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, that it is safe and without risks to health if it is used for a purpose for which it was designed, manufactured or supplied; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s30/1/b.content: give adequate information to each person to whom the supplier supplies the plant or substance concerning— (i) the purpose or purposes for which the plant or substance was designed, manufactured or supplied; and (ii) any conditions necessary to ensure that the plant or substance is safe and without risks to health if it is used for a purpose for which it was designed, manufactured or supplied; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s30/1/c.content: on request, give such information to a person who uses or is to use the plant or substance. Penalty: 1800 penalty units for a natural person; 9000 penalty units for a body corporate. Note to s. 29(2) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.8).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s30/2.content: For the purposes of subsection (1), if the person Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 34 who supplies the plant or substance—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s30/2/a.content: carries on the business of financing the acquisition of plant or a substance by customers; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s30/2/b.content: has, in the course of that business, acquired an interest in the plant or substance solely for the purpose of financing its acquisition by a customer from a third person or its provision to a customer by a third person; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s30/2/c.content: has not taken possession of the plant or substance or has taken possession of it solely for the purpose of passing possession to that customer— the reference in subsection (1) to the person who supplies that plant or substance is instead taken to be a reference to the third person.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s30/3.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s31.title: Duties of persons installing, erecting or
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s31.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
35   
 (2) An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable 
offence. 
Note 
However, the offence may be heard and determined 
summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 
2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s31/1.content: A person who installs, erects or commissions commissioning plant plant who knows, or ought reasonably to know, that the plant is to be used at a workplace must ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, that nothing about the way in which the plant is installed, erected or commissioned makes its use unsafe or a risk to health. Penalty: 1800 penalty units for a natural person; 9000 penalty units for a body corporate. Note to s. 30(3) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.9).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s31/2.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 35 offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s32.title: Duty not to recklessly endanger persons at
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s32.content:
workplaces 
A person who, without lawful excuse, recklessly 
engages in conduct that places or may place 
another person who is at a workplace in danger of 
serious injury is guilty of an indictable offence 
and liable to— 
 (a) in the case of a natural person, a term of 
imprisonment not exceeding 5 years, or a 
fine not exceeding 1800 penalty units, or 
both; and 
 (b) in the case of a body corporate, a fine not 
exceeding 20 000 penalty units. 
Note 
However, the offence may be heard and determined 
summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 
2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s32/a.content: in the case of a natural person, a term of workplaces A person who, without lawful excuse, recklessly engages in conduct that places or may place another person who is at a workplace in danger of serious injury is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to— imprisonment not exceeding 5 years, or a fine not exceeding 1800 penalty units, or both; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s32/b.content: in the case of a body corporate, a fine not exceeding 20 000 penalty units. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s33.title: Single charge for multiple contraventions of certain
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s33.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
36   
 (b) a contravention of such a provision for which 
an officer of a body corporate, partnership or 
unincorporated body or association 
(including a body corporate, partnership or 
unincorporated body or association 
representing the Crown) is liable. 
Note 
For liability of officers, see Divisions 4 and 5 of Part 11.  
 (2) Subject to any contrary court order, two or more 
contraventions may be charged as a single offence 
if they arise out of the same factual circumstances. 
 (3) This section does not authorise contraventions of 
two or more provisions of Division 2, 3, 4 or 5 to 
be charged as a single offence. 
 (4) If two or more contraventions are charged as a 
single offence, a single penalty only may be 
imposed in respect of the contraventions.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s33/1/a.content: a contravention of a provision of Division 2, 3, 4 or 5 by a person; and Note to s. 31(2) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.10). amended by No. 41/2016 s. 5. Note to s. 32 amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.11).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s33/b.content: a contravention of such a provision for which Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 36 an officer of a body corporate, partnership or unincorporated body or association (including a body corporate, partnership or unincorporated body or association representing the Crown) is liable. Note For liability of officers, see Divisions 4 and 5 of Part 11.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s33/2.content: Subject to any contrary court order, two or more contraventions may be charged as a single offence if they arise out of the same factual circumstances.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s33/3.content: This section does not authorise contraventions of two or more provisions of Division 2, 3, 4 or 5 to be charged as a single offence.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s33/4.content: If two or more contraventions are charged as a single offence, a single penalty only may be imposed in respect of the contraventions.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s34.title: Civil liability not affected by this Part
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s34.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
37

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s34/a.content: conferring a right of action in civil Nothing in this Part is to be construed as— proceedings in respect of a contravention of a provision of this Part; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s34/b.content: conferring a defence to an action in civil proceedings or otherwise affecting a right of action in civil proceedings; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s34/c.content: affecting the extent (if any) to which a right of action arises, or civil proceedings may be taken, with respect to breaches of duties or obligations imposed by the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35.title: Duty of employers to consult with employees
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
39   
 (b) giving the employees a reasonable 
opportunity to express their views 
about the matter; and 
 (c) taking into account those views. 
 (4) If the employees are represented by a health 
and safety representative, the consultation must 
involve that representative (with or without the 
involvement of the employees directly). 
 (5) Subject to subsections (3) and (4), if the employer 
and the employees have agreed to procedures for 
undertaking consultations, the consultation must 
be undertaken in accordance with those 
procedures. 
 (6) An employer who contravenes this section is 
guilty of an offence. 
Penalty: In the case of a natural person, 
180 penalty units;  
In the case of a body corporate, 
900 penalty units.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/1.content: When doing any of the following things, an employer must so far as is reasonably practicable consult in accordance with this section with the employees of the employer who are or are likely to be directly affected by the employer doing that thing—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/1/a.content: identifying or assessing hazards or risks to health or safety at a workplace under the employer's management and control or arising from the conduct of the undertaking of the employer;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/1/b.content: making decisions about the measures to be taken to control risks to health or safety at a workplace under the employer's management and control or arising from the conduct of the undertaking of the employer;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/1/c.content: making decisions about the adequacy of facilities for the welfare of employees of the employer;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/1/d.content: making decisions about the procedures for any of the following— (i) resolving health or safety issues at a workplace under the employer's management and control or arising from the conduct of the undertaking of the employer; (ii) consulting with employees of the employer in accordance with this section; (iii) monitoring the health of employees of the employer and the conditions at any workplace under the employer's management and control; substituted by No. 49/2018 s. 19.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/e.content: determining the membership of any health Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 38 (iv) providing information and training to employees of the employer; and safety committee;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/f.content: proposing changes, that may affect the health or safety of employees of the employer, to any of the following— (i) a workplace under the employer's management and control; (ii) the plant, substances or other things used at such a workplace; (iii) the conduct of the work performed at such a workplace;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/g.content: any other thing prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this subsection.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/2/a.content: a reference to an employee of an employer includes a reference to an independent contractor engaged by the employer and any employees of the independent contractor; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/2/b.content: the duties of an employer under that subsection extend to an independent contractor engaged by the employer, and any employees of the independent contractor, in relation to matters over which the employer has control or would have control if not for any agreement purporting to limit or remove that control.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/3.content: An employer who is required to consult with employees under subsection (1) must do so by—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/3/a.content: sharing with the employees information about the matter on which the employer is required to consult; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/b.content: giving the employees a reasonable Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 39 opportunity to express their views about the matter; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/4.content: If the employees are represented by a health and safety representative, the consultation must involve that representative (with or without the involvement of the employees directly).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/5.content: Subject to subsections (3) and (4), if the employer and the employees have agreed to procedures for undertaking consultations, the consultation must be undertaken in accordance with those procedures.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35/6.content: An employer who contravenes this section is guilty of an offence. Penalty: In the case of a natural person, 180 penalty units; In the case of a body corporate, 900 penalty units.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35A.title: Duty to consult with other employers in relation to
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35A.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
40   
 (2) Each person who has a duty in relation to the 
same worker must, so far as is reasonably 
practicable, consult, co-operate and co-ordinate 
activities with each other person who has a duty in 
relation to the same worker. 
Penalty: 180 penalty units for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35A/1.content: This section applies if— duties relating to labour hire

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35A/1/a.content: a person is taken to be an employer of a worker under section 5A; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35A/1/b.content: as a result, the person has duties under this Act in relation to the worker; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35A/1/c.content: one or more other persons have a duty in relation to the same worker, whether because the other person or persons are taken to be an employer of the worker under section 5A or because the worker is otherwise an employee of the other person or persons. inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 5.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s35A/2.content: Each person who has a duty in relation to the Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 40 same worker must, so far as is reasonably practicable, consult, co-operate and co-ordinate activities with each other person who has a duty in relation to the same worker. Penalty: 180 penalty units for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s900.title: penalty units for a body corporate.
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s900.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004

41

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37.title: Incidents to which this Part applies
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
44

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/1.content: This Part applies to an incident that results in—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/1/a.content: the death of a person; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/1/b.content: a person requiring medical treatment within 48 hours of exposure to a substance; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/1/c.content: a person requiring immediate treatment as an in-patient in a hospital; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/1/d.content: a person requiring immediate medical treatment for— (i) the amputation of any part of his or her body; or (ii) a serious head injury; or (iii) a serious eye injury; or (iv) the separation of his or her skin from an underlying tissue (such as de-gloving or scalping); or (v) electric shock; or (vi) a spinal injury; or (vii) the loss of a bodily function; or (viii) serious lacerations; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/1/e.content: any other injury to a person or other consequence prescribed by the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/2.content: This Part also applies to an incident that exposes a person to a serious risk to the person's health or safety emanating from an immediate or imminent exposure to—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/2/a.content: an uncontrolled escape, spillage or leakage of any substance, including dangerous goods within the meaning of the Dangerous Goods Act 1985; or substituted by No. 10/2022 s. 47(1).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/b.content: an implosion, explosion or fire; or Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 42

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/d.content: the fall or release from a height of any plant, substance or thing; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/e.content: the collapse, overturning, failure or malfunction of, or damage to, any plant (including plant in relation to a mine)— (i) that is prescribed by the regulations; or (ii) the design of which must be registered in accordance with the regulations; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/f.content: the collapse or partial collapse of a building or structure; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/g.content: the collapse or failure of an excavation or mine or of any shoring supporting an excavation or mine; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/h.content: the inrush of water, mud or gas in workings in a mine, underground excavation or tunnel; or (i) the interruption of the main system of ventilation in a mine, underground excavation or tunnel; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/j.content: any other event or circumstance prescribed by the regulations. (2A) Without limiting subsections (1) and (2), this Part also applies to an incident constituted by the illness of a person, being an illness prescribed by the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/3.content: Despite subsections (1), (2) and (2A), this Part does not apply to an incident of a kind excluded by the regulations. inserted by No. 10/2022 s. 47(2). amended by No. 10/2022 s. 47(3).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/4.content: In this section— Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 43 medical treatment means treatment by a person registered under the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law to practise in the medical or nursing or midwifery profession (other than as a student); mine means—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/4/a.content: a workplace at which work is being performed under a licence within the meaning of the Mineral Resources (Sustainable Development) Act 1990— (i) including work that is exploration (within the meaning of that Act), in the form of underground work of any kind or drilling from the surface for coal-bed methane; and (ii) excluding work that is exploration carried out above ground, other than drilling from the surface for coal-bed methane; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s37/4/b.content: all parts of a tourist mine that are underground and all infrastructure and plant associated with the underground workings; tourist mine means a mine, part of a mine, or any other location in which the principal activities conducted are those promoting interest in the practice and history of prospecting or mining. medical treatment amended by No. 97/2005 s. 182(Sch. 4 item 38), substituted by No. 13/2010 s. 51(Sch. item 39), amended by No. 48/2017 s. 11(a). mine amended by No. 63/2006 s. 61(Sch. item 26.1), substituted by No. 48/2017 s. 11(b). tourist mine inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 11(c).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38.title: Duty to notify of incidents
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
45   
 (ii) the members of each health and safety 
committee (if any) established by the 
employer. 
 (5) An employer or self-employed person who 
contravenes subsection (1), (3) or (4) is guilty of 
an offence and liable to a fine not exceeding— 
 (a) in the case of a natural person, 240 penalty 
units; or 
 (b) in the case of a body corporate, 1200 penalty 
units. 
 (6) An offence against subsection (5) is an indictable 
offence. 
Note 
However, the offence may be heard and determined 
summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure 
Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38/1.content: An employer or self-employed person must not, without reasonable excuse, fail to notify the Authority immediately after becoming aware that an incident has occurred at a workplace under the management and control of the employer or self-employed person.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38/2.content: However, an employer or self-employed person is not required to notify the Authority if the employer or self-employed person is the only person injured or otherwise harmed, or exposed to risk, as described in section 37 by the incident.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38/3.content: Within 48 hours after being required to notify the Authority, the employer or self-employed person must also give the Authority a written record of the incident, in the form approved in writing by the Authority.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38/4.content: The employer or self-employed person must keep a copy of the record for at least 5 years and make a copy of the record available for inspection by—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38/4/b.content: a person, or a representative of a person, injured in the incident or whose health or safety was exposed to serious risk by the incident; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38/4/c.content: a representative of a person whose death was caused by the incident; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38/4/d.content: in the case only of an employer— (i) if any of the employees of the employer are members of a designated work group, a health and safety representative for the designated work group; or amended by No. 48/2017 s. 12(1). amended by No. 10/2022 s. 48.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38/5.content: An employer or self-employed person who Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 45 (ii) the members of each health and safety committee (if any) established by the employer. contravenes subsection (1), (3) or (4) is guilty of an offence and liable to a fine not exceeding—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38/5/a.content: in the case of a natural person, 240 penalty units; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38/5/b.content: in the case of a body corporate, 1200 penalty units.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s38/6.content: An offence against subsection (5) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39.title: Duty to preserve incident sites
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39.content:
(1) An employer or self-employed person who is 
required to notify the Authority of an incident that 
has occurred at a workplace must not, without 
reasonable excuse, fail to ensure that the site 
where it occurred is not disturbed until— 
 (a) an inspector arrives at the site; or 
 (b) such other time as an inspector directs when 
the Authority is notified of the incident. 
Penalty: 240 penalty units for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39/1.content: An employer or self-employed person who is required to notify the Authority of an incident that has occurred at a workplace must not, without reasonable excuse, fail to ensure that the site where it occurred is not disturbed until—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39/1/a.content: an inspector arrives at the site; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39/1/b.content: such other time as an inspector directs when the Authority is notified of the incident. Penalty: 240 penalty units for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1200.title: penalty units for a body corporate.
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1200.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
47

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1200/2.content: Despite subsection (1), a site may be disturbed for the purpose of—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1200/2/a.content: protecting the health or safety of a person; or substituted by No. 48/2017 s. 12(2). substituted by No. 48/2017 s. 12(2). inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 12(3). amended by No. 48/2017 s. 13(1)(2).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1200/b.content: aiding an injured person involved in an Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 46 incident; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1200/c.content: taking essential action to make the site safe or to prevent a further occurrence of an incident.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1200/3.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009). inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 13(3).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39A.title: Objects of Part 5A
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39A.content:
The objects of this Part are— 
 (a) to prevent workplace deaths; and 
 (b) to deter persons who owe certain duties 
under Part 3 from breaching those duties; 
and 
 (c) to reflect the severity of conduct that places 
life at risk in the workplace.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39A/a.content: to prevent workplace deaths; and The objects of this Part are—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39A/b.content: to deter persons who owe certain duties under Part 3 from breaching those duties; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39A/c.content: to reflect the severity of conduct that places life at risk in the workplace.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39B.title: Definitions
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39B.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
48

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39B/a.content: the duty imposed by section 25; or In this Part— applicable duty means a duty imposed by a provision of Part 3 other than—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39B/b.content: a duty imposed by section 32 on a person who is an employee, but not an officer, at the workplace in relation to which the duty is imposed; conduct has the meaning given in section 39C; constitute a breach of an applicable duty has the meaning given in section 39D; negligent has the meaning given in section 39E; owes an applicable duty to another person has the meaning given in section 39F. Pt 5A (Headings and ss 39A–39G) inserted by No. 50/2019 s. 3. S 39A inserted by No. 50/2019 s. 3. S 39B inserted by No. 50/2019 s. 3.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39C.title: What does conduct mean?
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39C.content:
(1) For the purposes of this Part, conduct means— 
 (a) an act; or 
 (b) an omission to perform an act. 
 (2) An omission to perform an act on or after the 
commencement of this Part is conduct for the 
purposes of this Part regardless of whether an 
occasion for performing that act arose before that 
commencement.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39C/1.content: For the purposes of this Part, conduct means—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39C/1/b.content: an omission to perform an act.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39C/2.content: An omission to perform an act on or after the commencement of this Part is conduct for the purposes of this Part regardless of whether an occasion for performing that act arose before that commencement.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39D.title: When may conduct constitute a breach of an
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39D.content:
applicable duty? 
Conduct may constitute a breach of an applicable 
duty for the purposes of this Part— 
 (a) whether or not any other conduct also 
contributed to the breach; and 
 (b) whether or not any proceeding has been 
commenced in respect of that breach.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39D/a.content: whether or not any other conduct also applicable duty? Conduct may constitute a breach of an applicable duty for the purposes of this Part— contributed to the breach; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39D/b.content: whether or not any proceeding has been commenced in respect of that breach.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39E.title: When is conduct negligent?
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39E.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
49   
 (a) what matters is the conduct engaged in by 
the body corporate itself; and 
 (b) it does not matter whether the conduct is, or 
is not, conduct imputed to the body corporate 
under section 143; and 
 (c) it does not matter whether any of the body 
corporate's officers were involved in all or 
any part of the conduct; and 
 (d) the standard to be applied under 
subsection (1)(a) is the standard of care that 
would have been taken by a reasonable body 
corporate in the circumstances in which the 
conduct was engaged in.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39E/1.content: Conduct is negligent for the purposes of this Part if it involves—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39E/1/a.content: a great falling short of the standard of care that would have been taken by a reasonable person in the circumstances in which the conduct was engaged in; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39E/1/b.content: a high risk of— (i) death; or (ii) serious injury; or (iii) serious illness.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39E/2.content: In determining whether conduct engaged in by a body corporate is negligent for the purposes of this Part— S 39C inserted by No. 50/2019 s. 3. S 39D inserted by No. 50/2019 s. 3. S 39E inserted by No. 50/2019 s. 3.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39E/a.content: what matters is the conduct engaged in by Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 49 the body corporate itself; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39E/b.content: it does not matter whether the conduct is, or is not, conduct imputed to the body corporate under section 143; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39E/c.content: it does not matter whether any of the body corporate's officers were involved in all or any part of the conduct; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39E/d.content: the standard to be applied under subsection (1)(a) is the standard of care that would have been taken by a reasonable body corporate in the circumstances in which the conduct was engaged in.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39G.title: Workplace manslaughter
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39G.content:
(1) A person who is not a volunteer must not engage 
in conduct that— 
 (a) is negligent; and 
 (b) constitutes a breach of an applicable duty 
that the person owes to another person; and 
 (c) causes the death of that other person. 
Penalty: Imprisonment for 25 years for a natural 
person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39G/1.content: A person who is not a volunteer must not engage in conduct that—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39G/1/b.content: constitutes a breach of an applicable duty that the person owes to another person; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s39G/1/c.content: causes the death of that other person. Penalty: Imprisonment for 25 years for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40.title: Requirements for licence or registration
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
53   
 (4) A person must not carry out work, or an activity, 
at a workplace if— 
 (a) the regulations require the work or activity, 
or class of work or activity, to be carried out 
by a person who is registered or licensed; 
and 
 (b) the person is not registered or licensed 
(as the case may be) in accordance with the 
regulations. 
Penalty: 100 penalty units for a natural person; 
500 penalty units for a body corporate. 
 (5) An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable 
offence. 
Note 
However, the offence may be heard and determined 
summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 
2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/1.content: An employer or self-employed person must not conduct an undertaking at a workplace if—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/1/a.content: the regulations require the workplace, or class of workplace, to be licensed or registered; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/1/b.content: the workplace, or class of workplace, is not licensed or registered (as the case may be) in accordance with the regulations. Penalty: 500 penalty units for a natural person; 2500 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/2.content: A person must not use plant at a workplace if—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/2/a.content: the regulations require the plant or its design to be licensed or registered; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/2/b.content: the plant or its design (as the case may be) is not licensed or registered (as the case may be) in accordance with the regulations. Penalty: 100 penalty units for a natural person; 500 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/3.content: A person must not use a substance at a workplace if—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/3/a.content: the regulations require the substance to be licensed or registered; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/3/b.content: the substance is not licensed or registered (as the case may be) in accordance with the regulations. Penalty: 100 penalty units for a natural person; 500 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/4.content: A person must not carry out work, or an activity, Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 53 at a workplace if—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/4/a.content: the regulations require the work or activity, or class of work or activity, to be carried out by a person who is registered or licensed; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/4/b.content: the person is not registered or licensed (as the case may be) in accordance with the regulations. Penalty: 100 penalty units for a natural person; 500 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s40/5.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s43.title: Establishment of designated work groups
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s43.content:
(1) An employee may ask his or her employer to 
establish designated work groups of employees of 
the employer at one or more workplaces. 
 (2) The particulars of the designated work groups are 
to be determined by negotiation, in accordance 
with section 44, between the employer and 
employees. 
 (3) The employer must do everything reasonable to 
ensure that negotiations start within 14 days after 
the request. 
Penalty: 10 penalty units for a natural person; 
50 penalty units for a body corporate. 
 (4) An employer may initiate negotiations with 
employees of the employer to establish designated 
work groups.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s43/1.content: An employee may ask his or her employer to establish designated work groups of employees of the employer at one or more workplaces.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s43/2.content: The particulars of the designated work groups are to be determined by negotiation, in accordance with section 44, between the employer and employees.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s43/3.content: The employer must do everything reasonable to ensure that negotiations start within 14 days after the request. Penalty: 10 penalty units for a natural person; 50 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s43/4.content: An employer may initiate negotiations with employees of the employer to establish designated work groups.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44.title: Negotiation of agreement concerning designated
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
57   
 (4) If a variation is agreed, the employer must vary 
the agreement by giving written notice to the 
employees. 
Penalty: 10 penalty units for a natural person; 
50 penalty units for a body corporate. 
 (5) In negotiations concerning a designated work 
group or groups (including negotiations for a 
variation of an agreement), an employee or a 
group of employees may be represented by any 
person authorised by the employee or group 
(as the case may be). 
 (6) An agreement concerning a designated work 
group or groups must only deal with the 
particulars mentioned in subsection (1). 
Note 
Certain matters must be taken into account in negotiations 
for an agreement or a variation of an agreement (see 
section 46).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44/1.content: Negotiations concerning designated work groups work groups under this Division must be directed only at the following—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44/1/a.content: the manner of grouping, into one or more designated work groups, employees at one or more workplaces that— (i) best and most conveniently enables the interests of those employees relating to occupational health and safety to be represented and safeguarded; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44/b.content: the number (which must be at least one) of Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 56 (ii) best takes account of the need for a health and safety representative for the designated work group or groups to be accessible to each member of the group; health and safety representatives for each designated work group;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44/c.content: the number of deputy health and safety representatives (if any) for each designated work group;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44/d.content: the term of office (not exceeding 3 years) of each health and safety representative and deputy health and safety representative (if any);

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44/e.content: whether the health and safety representative or representatives for the designated work group or groups are authorised also to represent independent contractors, or a class of independent contractors, engaged by the employer, and any employees of such independent contractors, who work at a workplace at which members of the designated work group or groups work.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44/2.content: If the negotiations result in agreement on the particulars mentioned in subsection (1), the employer must establish the designated work group or groups (as agreed) by giving written notice to the employees. Penalty: 10 penalty units for a natural person; 50 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44/3.content: The parties to an agreement concerning a designated work group or groups may, at any time, negotiate a variation of the agreement.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44/4.content: If a variation is agreed, the employer must vary Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 57 the agreement by giving written notice to the employees. Penalty: 10 penalty units for a natural person; 50 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44/5.content: In negotiations concerning a designated work group or groups (including negotiations for a variation of an agreement), an employee or a group of employees may be represented by any person authorised by the employee or group (as the case may be).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s44/6.content: An agreement concerning a designated work group or groups must only deal with the particulars mentioned in subsection (1). Note Certain matters must be taken into account in negotiations for an agreement or a variation of an agreement (see section 46).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s45.title: Determination by inspector of unresolved
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s45.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
58

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s45/1.content: Any of the parties to a negotiation concerning a particulars designated work group or groups (including a variation of an agreement) under this Division may, if agreement is not reached within a reasonable time, ask the Authority to arrange for an inspector to determine the particulars that are unresolved.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s45/2.content: An inspector who determines unresolved particulars must give written notice of the determination to the parties and the parties must give effect to the determination.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s46.title: Matters to be taken into account

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s46/a.content: the number of employees at the workplace or The following matters must be taken into account in negotiations concerning a designated work group or groups (including negotiations for a variation of an agreement) under this Division or in determining unresolved particulars under section 45— workplaces;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s46/b.content: the nature of each type of work performed at the workplace or workplaces;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s46/c.content: the number and grouping of employees who perform the same or similar types of work or who work under the same or similar arrangements;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s46/d.content: the areas at the workplace or workplaces where each type of work is performed;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s46/e.content: the nature of any hazards at the workplace or workplaces;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s46/f.content: any overtime or shift working arrangements at the workplace or workplaces;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s46/g.content: whether other languages are spoken by the employees.
