/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s50.title: Guidelines for negotiations involving multiple
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s50.content:
employers  
 (1) The Authority may publish guidelines about 
conducting negotiations concerning designated 
work groups (including negotiations for a 
variation of an agreement) under this Division. 
 (2) The parties to such negotiations must have regard 
to the guidelines (if any) in conducting those 
negotiations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s50/1.content: The Authority may publish guidelines about employers conducting negotiations concerning designated work groups (including negotiations for a variation of an agreement) under this Division.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s50/2.content: The parties to such negotiations must have regard to the guidelines (if any) in conducting those negotiations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s51.title: Withdrawal from negotiations or agreement
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s51.content:
involving multiple employers  
 (1) A party to a negotiation for an agreement, or to an 
agreement, concerning a designated work group 
under this Division may withdraw from the 
negotiation or agreement at any time by giving 
reasonable notice (in writing) to the other parties. 
 (2) If a party withdraws from an agreement 
concerning a designated work group under this 
Division— 
 (a) the other parties must negotiate a variation to 
the agreement in accordance with section 48; 
and 
 (b) the withdrawal does not affect the validity of 
the agreement between the other parties in 
the meantime.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s51/1.content: A party to a negotiation for an agreement, or to an involving multiple employers agreement, concerning a designated work group under this Division may withdraw from the negotiation or agreement at any time by giving reasonable notice (in writing) to the other parties.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s51/2.content: If a party withdraws from an agreement concerning a designated work group under this Division—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s51/2/a.content: the other parties must negotiate a variation to the agreement in accordance with section 48; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s51/2/b.content: the withdrawal does not affect the validity of the agreement between the other parties in the meantime.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s52.title: Effect of Division on other arrangements

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s53.title: Prohibition on coercion
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s53.content:
(1) A person must not coerce or attempt to coerce 
another person— 
 (a) not to make, or to withdraw, a request under 
section 43; or 
 (b) in the conduct of negotiations concerning a 
designated work group or groups (including 
negotiations for a variation of an agreement) 
under Division 1 or 2; or 
 (c) in relation to the other person being 
represented in such negotiations. 
Penalty: 60 penalty units for a natural person; 
300 penalty units for a body corporate. 
 (2) The Magistrates' Court may grant an injunction 
requiring a person not to contravene or to cease 
contravening subsection (1). 
 (3) If a court convicts a person or finds a person 
guilty of an offence against subsection (1), the 
court may make any order that it considers 
appropriate relating to the validity of all or part of 
an agreement under Division 1 or 2 (as the case 
may be).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s53/1.content: A person must not coerce or attempt to coerce another person—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s53/1/a.content: not to make, or to withdraw, a request under section 43; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s53/1/b.content: in the conduct of negotiations concerning a designated work group or groups (including negotiations for a variation of an agreement) under Division 1 or 2; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s53/1/c.content: in relation to the other person being represented in such negotiations. Penalty: 60 penalty units for a natural person; 300 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s53/2.content: The Magistrates' Court may grant an injunction requiring a person not to contravene or to cease contravening subsection (1).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s53/3.content: If a court convicts a person or finds a person guilty of an offence against subsection (1), the court may make any order that it considers appropriate relating to the validity of all or part of an agreement under Division 1 or 2 (as the case may be).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s54.title: Election of health and safety representatives
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s54.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
65

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s54/1.content: A health and safety representative for a designated work group is to be elected by the members of the designated work group.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s54/2.content: A person is— Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 64

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s54/2/a.content: only eligible to be elected as a health and safety representative for a designated work group if he or she is a member of that group; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s54/2/b.content: not eligible to be elected as a health and safety representative if he or she is disqualified under section 56 from acting as a health and safety representative.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s54/3.content: All members of the designated work group are entitled to vote in an election.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s54/4.content: The members of the designated work group may determine how an election is to be conducted (subject to subsection (5)) but, if they do not reach agreement within a reasonable time, any member may ask the Authority to arrange for an inspector to—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s54/4/b.content: if the inspector considers it appropriate, appoint another person to conduct the election.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s54/5.content: An election must be conducted in accordance with the procedures (if any) prescribed by the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s54/6.content: If the number of candidates for election as a health and safety representative equals the number of vacancies, the election need not be conducted and each candidate is to be taken to have been elected as a health and safety representative for the designated work group.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55.title: Term of office
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
66   
 (e) the designated work group is varied unless, 
as part of the variation, it is agreed or an 
inspector determines under section 45 that 
the variation is not to affect the remaining 
term of office of that health and safety 
representative. 
 (3) A health and safety representative is eligible for 
re-election.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55/1.content: A health and safety representative for a designated work group holds office for the following period (not exceeding 3 years)—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55/1/a.content: the period agreed, or determined by an inspector under section 45, when the particulars of the designated work group were determined;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55/1/b.content: that period as varied under section 44 or 48— starting on the day on which the representative is elected.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55/2.content: However, a person ceases to hold office as a health and safety representative for a designated work group if—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55/2/a.content: the person ceases to be a member of the designated work group; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55/2/b.content: the person is disqualified under section 56 from acting as a health and safety representative; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55/2/c.content: the person resigns as the health and safety representative by giving written notice to the employer, or any of the employers, concerned; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55/2/d.content: a majority of the members of the designated work group resolve (in writing) that the person should no longer represent the designated work group but only if the person has held office for at least 12 months; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55/e.content: the designated work group is varied unless, Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 66 as part of the variation, it is agreed or an inspector determines under section 45 that the variation is not to affect the remaining term of office of that health and safety representative.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s55/3.content: A health and safety representative is eligible for re-election.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s56.title: Disqualification of health and safety representatives
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s56.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
67   
 (3) For the purpose of determining what (if any) 
action to take under subsection (2), the 
Magistrates' Court must take into account— 
 (a) what (if any) harm was caused to the 
employer or the undertaking of the employer 
by or as a result of the action of the health 
and safety representative; and 
 (b) the past record of the health and safety 
representative in exercising powers under 
this Part.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s56/1.content: An employer may apply to the Magistrates' Court to have a health and safety representative disqualified on the ground that the representative has done any of the following things intending to cause harm to the employer or the undertaking of the employer—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s56/1/a.content: issued a provisional improvement notice to the employer or an employee of the employer in circumstances where the representative could not reasonably have held the belief referred to in section 60;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s56/1/b.content: issued a direction to cease work under section 74;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s56/1/c.content: exercised any other power under this Part;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s56/1/d.content: used any information he or she acquired from the employer for a purpose that is not connected with his or her exercise of a power under this Part.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s56/2.content: If the Magistrates' Court is satisfied that the ground in subsection (1) is established, it may disqualify the health and safety representative for a specified period or permanently.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s56/3.content: For the purpose of determining what (if any) Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 67 action to take under subsection (2), the Magistrates' Court must take into account—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s56/3/a.content: what (if any) harm was caused to the employer or the undertaking of the employer by or as a result of the action of the health and safety representative; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s56/3/b.content: the past record of the health and safety representative in exercising powers under this Part.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s57/1.content: Each deputy health and safety representative for a designated work group is to be elected in the same way as a health and safety representative for the designated work group.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s57/2.content: If the health and safety representative for a designated work group ceases to hold office or is unable (because of absence or any other reason) to exercise the powers of a health and safety representative under this Part—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s57/2/a.content: the powers may be exercised by a deputy health and safety representative (if any) for the designated work group; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s57/2/b.content: this Act (other than this section) applies in relation to the deputy health and safety representative accordingly.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s57/3.content: Sections 55, 56 and 67 apply to deputy health and safety representatives in the same way as they apply to health and safety representatives. Note Those sections deal with term of office, disqualification of health and safety representatives and the obligation of employers to train health and safety representatives.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58.title: Powers of health and safety representatives
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
70   
whom the representative is authorised to 
represent, that arise at the workplace or 
workplaces or from the conduct of the 
undertaking of the employer. 
 (3) Nothing in this Act or the regulations imposes, or 
is to be taken to impose, a function or duty on a 
health and safety representative in that capacity.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/1.content: A health and safety representative for a designated work group may do any of the following—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/1/a.content: inspect any part of a workplace at which a member of the designated work group works— (i) at any time after giving reasonable notice to the employer concerned or its representative; and (ii) immediately in the event of an incident or any situation involving an immediate risk to the health or safety of any person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/1/ab.content: take photographs or measurements or make sketches or recordings at any part of a workplace at which a member of the designated work group works, other than during an interview under paragraph (d) or (e);

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/1/b.content: accompany an inspector during an inspection of a workplace at which a member of the designated work group works;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/1/c.content: require the establishment of a health and safety committee;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/1/d.content: if a member of the designated work group consents, be present at an interview concerning occupational health and safety between— (i) the member and an inspector; or (ii) the member and the employer concerned or its representative; inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 29.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/e.content: if the health and safety representative is Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 69 authorised to represent a person mentioned in section 44(1)(e) or 48(1)(e) and that person consents, be present at an interview concerning occupational health and safety between— (i) the person and an inspector; or (ii) the person and the employer concerned or its representative;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/f.content: whenever necessary, seek the assistance of any person.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/2.content: However, a health and safety representative may do those things only for the purpose of—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/2/a.content: representing the members of the designated work group, or persons mentioned in section 44(1)(e) or 48(1)(e) whom the representative is authorised to represent, concerning health or safety; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/2/b.content: monitoring the measures taken by the employer or employers in compliance with this Act or the regulations; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/2/c.content: enquiring into anything that poses, or may pose, a risk to the health or safety of members of the designated work group, or of persons mentioned in section 44(1)(e) or 48(1)(e) whom the representative is authorised to represent, at the workplace or workplaces or arising from the conduct of the undertaking of the employer or undertakings of the employers; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/2/d.content: attempting to resolve (in accordance with section 73) with the employer concerned or its representative any issues concerning the health or safety of members of the designated work group, or of persons mentioned in section 44(1)(e) or 48(1)(e)

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s58/3.content: Nothing in this Act or the regulations imposes, or Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 70 whom the representative is authorised to represent, that arise at the workplace or workplaces or from the conduct of the undertaking of the employer. is to be taken to impose, a function or duty on a health and safety representative in that capacity.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s59.title: Powers generally limited to the particular
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s59.content:
designated work group 
A health and safety representative for a designated 
work group may exercise powers under this Part 
only in respect of matters that affect, or may 
affect, members of that group, or persons 
mentioned in section 44(1)(e) or 48(1)(e) whom 
the representative is authorised to represent, 
unless— 
 (a) there is an immediate risk to health or safety 
that affects or may affect a member of 
another designated work group; or 
 (b) a member of another designated work group 
asks for the representative's assistance— 
and it is not feasible for the representative to refer 
the matter to a health and safety representative for 
the other designated work group.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s59/a.content: there is an immediate risk to health or safety designated work group A health and safety representative for a designated work group may exercise powers under this Part only in respect of matters that affect, or may affect, members of that group, or persons mentioned in section 44(1)(e) or 48(1)(e) whom the representative is authorised to represent, unless— that affects or may affect a member of another designated work group; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s59/b.content: a member of another designated work group asks for the representative's assistance— and it is not feasible for the representative to refer the matter to a health and safety representative for the other designated work group.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60.title: Provisional improvement notices
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
72   
 (i) bring the notice to the attention of each 
other person whose work is affected by 
the notice; and 
 (ii) display a copy of the notice in a 
prominent place at or near the 
workplace, or part of the workplace, at 
which work is being performed that is 
affected by the notice. 
Penalty: 5 penalty units for a natural person; 
25 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60/1.content: If a health and safety representative believes on reasonable grounds that a person—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60/1/a.content: is contravening a provision of this Act or the regulations; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60/1/b.content: has contravened such a provision in circumstances that make it likely that the contravention will continue or be repeated—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60/2.content: However, the health and safety representative may Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 71 the health and safety representative may issue to the person a provisional improvement notice requiring the person to remedy the contravention or likely contravention or the matters or activities causing the contravention or likely contravention. only do so after consulting with the person or, if the person is a body corporate, an employee, agent or officer of the body corporate, about remedying the contravention or likely contravention or the matters or activities causing the contravention or likely contravention.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60/3/a.content: state the representative's belief on which the issue of the notice is based and the grounds for that belief; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60/3/b.content: specify the provision of this Act or the regulations that the representative considers has been or is likely to be contravened; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60/3/c.content: specify a day (at least 8 days after the day on which the notice is issued) before which the person is required to remedy the contravention or likely contravention or the matters or activities causing the contravention or likely contravention. Note For service of provisional improvement notices, see section 64.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60/4.content: A person to whom a provisional improvement notice is issued must—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60/4/a.content: if the person is an employee, bring the notice to the attention of his or her employer; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s60/4/b.content: if the person is not an employee or is an employer who is given a copy of the notice in accordance with paragraph (a)— amended by No. 36/2021 s. 15.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s61.title: Provisional improvement notices may include
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s61.content:
directions 
 (1) A provisional improvement notice may include 
directions on the measures to be taken to remedy 
the contravention or likely contravention, or the 
matters or activities causing the contravention or 
likely contravention, to which the notice relates. 
 (2) A direction may— 
 (a) refer to a compliance code; and 
 (b) offer the person to whom it is issued a choice 
of ways in which to remedy the 
contravention, likely contravention, matters 
or activities.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s61/1.content: A provisional improvement notice may include directions directions on the measures to be taken to remedy the contravention or likely contravention, or the matters or activities causing the contravention or likely contravention, to which the notice relates.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s61/2/a.content: refer to a compliance code; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s61/2/b.content: offer the person to whom it is issued a choice of ways in which to remedy the contravention, likely contravention, matters or activities.

 (2) An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable 
offence. 
Note 
However, the offence may be heard and determined

Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s62/1.content: A person must comply with a provisional notice improvement notice issued to him or her in relation to which an inspector has not been required under section 63 to attend at the workplace. Penalty: 500 penalty units for a natural person; 2500 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s62/2.content: An offence against subsection (1) is an indictable Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 73 offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

 (a) the basis for the inspector's decision to 
affirm or cancel the provisional improvement 
notice; and 
 (b) if the provisional improvement notice is 
affirmed, the penalty for contravening that 
notice; and 
 (c) how the person may seek review of the 
inspector's decision. 
 (6) A person to whom a provisional improvement 
notice was issued that is affirmed by an inspector 
under this section must comply with the

Penalty: 500 penalty units for a natural person;

 (7) An offence against subsection (6) is an indictable

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/1.content: Within 7 days after a provisional improvement provisional improvement notice notice is issued to a person—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/1/a.content: the person to whom it was issued; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/1/b.content: if the person is an employee, his or her employer— may ask the Authority to arrange for an inspector to attend at the workplace to enquire into the circumstances the subject of the notice.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/2.content: The Authority must ensure that an inspector attends the workplace as soon as possible after the request is made and before the day specified in the notice as being the day by which the notice must be complied with.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/3.content: The inspector must, as soon as possible—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/3/a.content: enquire into the circumstances the subject of the provisional improvement notice; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/3/b.content: affirm (with or without modifications) or cancel the provisional improvement notice by giving written notice to the health and safety representative who issued it and the person to whom it was issued.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/4.content: The inspector may perform any of his or her functions or exercise any of his or her powers under this Act that the inspector considers reasonably necessary in the circumstances. Note to s. 62(2) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.13).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/5.content: A notice under subsection (3)(b) must set out— Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 74

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/5/a.content: the basis for the inspector's decision to affirm or cancel the provisional improvement notice; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/5/b.content: if the provisional improvement notice is affirmed, the penalty for contravening that notice; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/5/c.content: how the person may seek review of the inspector's decision.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/6.content: A person to whom a provisional improvement notice was issued that is affirmed by an inspector under this section must comply with the provisional improvement notice. Penalty: 500 penalty units for a natural person; 2500 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s63/7.content: An offence against subsection (6) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64.title: Issue etc. of provisional improvement notice or
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
76   
 (3) Subject to subsection (4), this section is 
in addition to, and not in derogation from, 
the Interpretation of Legislation Act 1984, 
the Electronic Transactions (Victoria)  
Act 2000 and sections 109X and 601CX of 
the Corporations Act. 
 (4) Section 8(1) and (2) of the Electronic 
Transactions (Victoria) Act 2000 do not 
apply to the issue or giving of a notice by 
electronic communication under this section.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/1.content: A provisional improvement notice, or notice given inspector's notice by an inspector under section 63(3)(b), may be issued or given to a person by—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/1/a.content: delivering it personally to the person or sending it by post or facsimile to the person's usual or last known place of residence or business; or Note to s. 63(7) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.14). (Heading) amended by No. 36/2021 s. 16(1). amended by No. 48/2017 s. 14(3) (ILA s. 39B(1)).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/b.content: leaving it for the person at the person's usual Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 75 or last known place of residence or business with a person who is apparently over 16 years and who apparently resides or works there; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/c.content: leaving it for the person at the workplace to which the notice relates with a person who is apparently over 16 years and who is apparently the occupier for the time being of the workplace; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/d.content: if the person to whom the notice is to be issued or given is not a body corporate, sending it by electronic communication to the person at the person's usual or last known electronic address; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/e.content: if the person is an employer registered under section 434 of the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013, sending it by post or electronic communication to the last address for service shown on a communication from the employer to the Authority.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/2.content: In addition to subsection (1), if the person to whom a notice is to be issued or given is a body corporate, the notice may be issued or given by—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/2/a.content: delivering it personally to the head office, registered office or principal place of business of the body corporate; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/2/b.content: sending it by post to the head office, registered office or principal place of business of the body corporate; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/2/c.content: sending it by electronic communication to an employee, agent or officer of the body corporate. amended by No. 48/2017 s. 14(1). inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 14(2), amended by No. 36/2021 s. 16(2). inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 14(2). inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 14(3), substituted by No. 36/2021 s. 16(3).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/3.content: Subject to subsection (4), this section is Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 76 in addition to, and not in derogation from, the Interpretation of Legislation Act 1984, the Electronic Transactions (Victoria) Act 2000 and sections 109X and 601CX of the Corporations Act.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s64/4.content: Section 8(1) and (2) of the Electronic Transactions (Victoria) Act 2000 do not apply to the issue or giving of a notice by electronic communication under this section.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s65.title: Formal irregularities or defects in provisional
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s65.content:
improvement notices 
A provisional improvement notice, or notice given 
by an inspector under section 63(3)(b), is not 
invalid merely because of— 
 (a) a formal defect or irregularity in the notice 
unless the defect or irregularity causes or is 
likely to cause substantial injustice; or 
 (b) a failure to use the correct name of the 
person to whom the notice is issued if the 
notice sufficiently identifies the person and 
is issued to the person in accordance with 
section 64.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s65/a.content: a formal defect or irregularity in the notice improvement notices A provisional improvement notice, or notice given by an inspector under section 63(3)(b), is not invalid merely because of— unless the defect or irregularity causes or is likely to cause substantial injustice; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s65/b.content: a failure to use the correct name of the person to whom the notice is issued if the notice sufficiently identifies the person and is issued to the person in accordance with section 64.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s66.title: Proceedings for offences not affected by notices

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67.title: Obligation to train health and safety representatives
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
79

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/1.content: An employer must, if requested by a health and safety representative for a designated work group of which employees of the employer are members, allow the representative to attend the following courses—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/1/a.content: an initial course of training in occupational health and safety after being elected;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/1/b.content: a refresher course at least once in each year, after completing the initial course of training, that he or she holds office.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/2.content: A request to attend a course must not be made less than 14 days before the course is to start.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/3/a.content: approved or conducted by the Authority; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/3/b.content: relevant to the work of the members of the designated work group or the role of health and safety representatives; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/3/c.content: subject to subsection (5), chosen by the health and safety representative in consultation with the employer.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/4/a.content: allow each health and safety representative time off work to attend the courses with such pay as he or she would otherwise be entitled to receive from the employer for working during that period; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/4/b.content: pay the costs associated with each health and safety representative's attendance at the courses.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/5.content: If an employer refuses to allow a health and safety Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 78 Note If the health and safety representative represents a designated work group of the employees of more than one employer, section 68 provides for the apportionment of those costs among the employers. representative to attend a course or they cannot agree on a particular course, the representative may ask the Authority to determine a specified course that the representative may attend for the purposes of subsection (1)(a) or (b).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/6.content: A determination must be in writing and the Authority must ensure that it is not made less than 14 days before the specified course is to start.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/7.content: An employer who, without reasonable excuse, refuses to allow a health and safety representative to attend a course specified in such a determination is guilty of an offence and liable to a fine not exceeding—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/7/a.content: in the case of a natural person, 60 penalty units; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/7/b.content: in the case of a body corporate, 300 penalty units.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/8/a.content: a health and safety representative represents a designated work group of the employees of more than one employer; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s67/8/b.content: any of those employers has complied with this section in respect of the representative— each of those employers is to be taken to have complied with this section in respect of the representative.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s68.title: Obligation to share costs if multiple employers
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s68.content:
(1) If a health and safety representative, or deputy 
health and safety representative (if any), 
represents a designated work group of the 
employees of more than one employer— 
 (a) the costs of the representative exercising 
powers under this Part; and 
 (b) the costs mentioned in section 67(4)(b)— 
for which any of the employers are liable must be 
apportioned equally between each of the 
employers unless they agree otherwise. 
 (2) An agreement to apportion the costs in another 
way may be varied at any time by negotiation 
between each employer.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s68/1.content: If a health and safety representative, or deputy health and safety representative (if any), represents a designated work group of the employees of more than one employer—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s68/1/a.content: the costs of the representative exercising powers under this Part; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s68/1/b.content: the costs mentioned in section 67(4)(b)— for which any of the employers are liable must be apportioned equally between each of the employers unless they agree otherwise.

are— 
 (a) to facilitate co-operation between the

developing and carrying out measures

 (b) to formulate, review and disseminate 
(in other languages if appropriate) to the

 (4) A health and safety committee must meet—

members require a meeting.

and safety committee may determine its own 
procedures.

Subdivision 1—Criminal offences and proceedings

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s75/1.content: If an issue is not resolved under section 73 within a reasonable time, or an issue is the subject of a direction under section 74 that work is to cease, any of the parties attempting to resolve the issue may ask the Authority to arrange for an inspector to attend at the workplace to enquire into the issue.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s75/2.content: The Authority must ensure that an inspector attends at the workplace as soon as possible after the request is made.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s75/3.content: The inspector must, as soon as possible, enquire into the issue and may perform any of his or her functions or exercise any of his or her powers under this Act that the inspector considers reasonably necessary in the circumstances.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s75/4/a.content: the inspector issues a prohibition notice; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s75/4/b.content: otherwise determines (in writing) that there was reasonable cause for employees to be concerned for their health or safety—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s75/5.content: A dispute concerning an entitlement under Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 86 an employee who, as a result of the issue arising, does not work for any period pending its resolution but would otherwise be entitled to be paid for that period continues to be entitled to be paid for that period. subsection (4) may be referred to the Magistrates' Court or to any other court or tribunal that has jurisdiction in relation to the matter.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s77.title: Accused bears onus of proof
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s77.content:
In proceedings for an offence against section 76, if 
all the facts constituting the offence other than the 
reason for the conduct of the accused are proved, 
the accused bears the onus of proving that the 
reason alleged in the charge was not the dominant 
reason why the accused engaged in the conduct.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78A.title: Prohibition of discriminatory conduct
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78A.content:
(1) An employer or prospective employer must not 
engage in discriminatory conduct for a prohibited 
reason. 
 (2) For the purposes of this subdivision, an employer 
or prospective employer engages in discriminatory 
conduct if— 
 (a) the employer of an employee— 
 (i) dismisses the employee, injures an 
employee in the employment of the 
employer or alters the position of the 
employee to the employee's detriment; 
or 
 (ii) threatens to do any of those things to 
the employee; or

employment to the prospective employee, or 
treats the prospective employee less 
favourably than another prospective 
employee would be treated in offering terms 
of employment.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78A/1.content: An employer or prospective employer must not engage in discriminatory conduct for a prohibited reason.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78A/2.content: For the purposes of this subdivision, an employer or prospective employer engages in discriminatory conduct if—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78A/2/a.content: the employer of an employee— (i) dismisses the employee, injures an employee in the employment of the employer or alters the position of the employee to the employee's detriment; or (ii) threatens to do any of those things to the employee; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78A/2/b.content: the employer or prospective employer of the prospective employee refuses or fails to offer employment to the prospective employee, or treats the prospective employee less favourably than another prospective employee would be treated in offering terms of employment.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78D/1.content: An eligible person may apply to the Industrial Division of the Magistrates' Court for an order under this section. amended by No. 48/2017 s. 16(1). amended by No. 48/2017 s. 16(2). inserted by No. 34/2009 s. 6. inserted by No. 34/2009 s. 6.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78D/2.content: The Industrial Division of the Magistrates' Court Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 91 may make one or more of the following orders in relation to an employer or prospective employer who has contravened section 78A—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78D/2/a.content: an order that the employer or prospective employer pay (within a specified period) such damages to the employee or prospective employee who was the subject of the discriminatory conduct as the Court considers appropriate to compensate the employee or prospective employee;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78D/2/b.content: an order that— (i) the employee be reinstated or re- employed in the employee's former position or, if that position is not available, in a similar position; or (ii) the prospective employee be employed in the position for which the prospective employee had applied or a similar position;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78D/2/c.content: any other order that the Court considers appropriate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78D/3.content: The Industrial Division of the Magistrates' Court may make one or more of the following orders in relation to a person who has contravened section 78C—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78D/3/a.content: an order that the accused pay (within a specified period) such damages to the person who was the subject of the discriminatory conduct as the Court considers appropriate to compensate the person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78D/3/b.content: any other order that the Court considers appropriate. amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.18).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78D/5/a.content: a person affected by the contravention;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78D/5/b.content: another person authorised to represent a person referred to in paragraph (a).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78D/6.content: Nothing in this section is to be construed as limiting any other power of the Industrial Division of the Magistrates' Court.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78E.title: Procedure for actions for discriminatory conduct

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78E/1.content: A proceeding brought for contravention of section 78A or 78C must be commenced not more than 1 year after the date on which the plaintiff knew or ought to have known that the cause of action accrued.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78E/2.content: In a proceeding for a contravention of section 78A or 78C, if all the facts constituting the alleged discriminatory conduct other than the reason for the conduct of the accused are proved, the accused bears the onus of proving that the reason alleged in the complaint was not a substantial reason for the conduct.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78E/3.content: It is a defence to a proceeding for a contravention of section 78A or 78C if the accused proves that—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78E/3/a.content: the conduct was reasonable in the circumstances; and inserted by No. 34/2009 s. 6. amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.19). amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.20).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78E/b.content: a substantial reason for the conduct was to Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 93 comply with the requirements of this Act or with the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78E/4.content: The making of an order in a proceeding for a contravention of section 78A does not prevent the bringing of a proceeding for an offence against section 76 in respect of the same conduct.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78E/5.content: If the Industrial Division of the Magistrates' Court makes an order under section 78D in a proceeding for a contravention of section 78A, the court cannot make an order under section 78 in a proceeding for an offence against section 76 in respect of the same conduct.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s78E/6.content: If the court makes an order under section 78 in a proceeding for an offence against section 76, the Industrial Division of the Magistrates' Court cannot make an order under section 78D in a proceeding for a contravention of section 78A in respect of the same conduct. amended by No. 67/2013 s. 649(Sch. 9 item 25(4)).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s80.content:
authorised representatives 
 (1) The Minister may, by notice published in the 
Government Gazette, make a determination 
limiting the number of persons who may hold an 
entry permit as an authorised representative of a 
registered employee organisation. 
 (2) Before making the determination, the Minister 
must take into account the advice given by the 
Authority's Board of Management.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s80/1.content: The Minister may, by notice published in the authorised representatives Government Gazette, make a determination limiting the number of persons who may hold an entry permit as an authorised representative of a registered employee organisation.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s81.title: Who may hold an entry permit
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s81.content:
A person may only hold an entry permit as an 
authorised representative of a registered employee 
organisation if he or she— 
 (a) is a permanent employee or officer of the 
organisation, whether engaged on a full-time 
or part-time basis; and 
 (b) has satisfactorily completed a course of 
training approved (in writing) by the 
Authority for the purposes of this paragraph; 
and 
 (c) is not disqualified from holding an entry 
permit by an order of the Magistrates' Court. 
Note 
For disqualification orders, see section 85.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s83/1.content: A member of the committee of management of a registered employee organisation, or of a branch of such an organisation, may apply to the Magistrates' Court for an entry permit to be issued to a person who is an officer or employee of the organisation as an authorised representative of the organisation.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s83/2.content: An application for an entry permit must specify the person who is to hold the entry permit and include a statutory declaration or affidavit declaring or deposing—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s83/2/a.content: that the person is qualified under section 81 to hold an entry permit; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s83/2/b.content: that the issue of the entry permit would not exceed the limit set out in the Minister's determination (if any) under section 80; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s83/2/c.content: whether— (i) any entry permits issued to the person have been revoked; or (ii) the person has been convicted or found guilty of an offence against this Part; or (iii) the person has been convicted or found guilty of any indictable offence within the previous 5 years.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s83/3.content: The Magistrates' Court may issue an entry permit to a person if it is satisfied about each of the matters in subsections (2)(a) and (b) and has had regard to the matters in subsection (2)(c).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s83/4.content: An entry permit must include the information Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 97 (if any) prescribed by the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s83/5.content: A person who holds an entry permit is an authorised representative of the registered employee organisation that applied for the permit.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s84.title: Expiry of entry permits
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s84.content:
(1) An entry permit issued to a person as an 
authorised representative of a registered employee 
organisation expires at the earlier of— 
 (a) 3 years after it is issued; or 
 (b) when the person ceases to be a permanent 
employee or officer of the organisation, 
whether engaged on a full-time or part-time 
basis; or 
 (c) when the organisation ceases to be a 
registered employee organisation. 
Note 
An entry permit may also be revoked (see section 85). 
 (2) Before an entry permit has expired, an application 
may be made for the issue of a subsequent entry 
permit.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s84/1.content: An entry permit issued to a person as an authorised representative of a registered employee organisation expires at the earlier of—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s84/1/a.content: 3 years after it is issued; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s84/1/b.content: when the person ceases to be a permanent employee or officer of the organisation, whether engaged on a full-time or part-time basis; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s84/1/c.content: when the organisation ceases to be a registered employee organisation. Note An entry permit may also be revoked (see section 85).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s84/2.content: Before an entry permit has expired, an application may be made for the issue of a subsequent entry permit.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85.title: Revocation and disqualification
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85.content:

98   
 (b) intentionally used or disclosed, for a purpose 
not reasonably connected with the exercise 
of a power under this Part, information that 
was acquired from any employer or 
employee. 
 (2) The applicant must give written notice of the 
application, setting out the grounds for it, to the 
person who holds the entry permit and the 
registered employee organisation concerned. 
 (3) The person who holds the entry permit and the 
registered employee organisation are parties to the 
application. 
 (4) If the Magistrates' Court is satisfied on the balance 
of probabilities about any of the matters in 
subsection (1)(a) or (b), it may make an order— 
 (a) revoking the entry permit; and 
 (b) if it considers it appropriate to do so, 
disqualifying the person from holding an 
entry permit for a specified period (of no 
more than 5 years). 
 (5) In deciding what action to take under 
subsection (4), the Magistrates' Court must take 
into account— 
 (a) the extent (if any) of harm, loss or damage 
caused; and 
 (b) the person's past record in exercising powers 
under this Part as an authorised 
representative.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85/1.content: The Authority or an employer may apply to the Magistrates' Court for an entry permit held by a person to be revoked because the person has—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85/1/a.content: in exercising or purporting to exercise a power under this Part— (i) intentionally hindered or obstructed any employer or employee; or (ii) acted unreasonably or otherwise than for the purposes of exercising a power under this Part; or amended by No. 48/2017 s. 17.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85/b.content: intentionally used or disclosed, for a purpose Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 98 not reasonably connected with the exercise of a power under this Part, information that was acquired from any employer or employee.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85/2.content: The applicant must give written notice of the application, setting out the grounds for it, to the person who holds the entry permit and the registered employee organisation concerned.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85/3.content: The person who holds the entry permit and the registered employee organisation are parties to the application.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85/4.content: If the Magistrates' Court is satisfied on the balance of probabilities about any of the matters in subsection (1)(a) or (b), it may make an order—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85/4/b.content: if it considers it appropriate to do so, disqualifying the person from holding an entry permit for a specified period (of no more than 5 years).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85/5.content: In deciding what action to take under subsection (4), the Magistrates' Court must take into account—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85/5/a.content: the extent (if any) of harm, loss or damage caused; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s85/5/b.content: the person's past record in exercising powers under this Part as an authorised representative.

 (4) In this section— 
certified agreement means a pre-reform certified

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s87/1.content: This section applies if an authorised representative of a registered employee organisation reasonably suspects that a contravention of this Act or the regulations has occurred or is occurring at a place that is a workplace and any of the following paragraphs applies—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s87/1/a.content: the suspected contravention relates to or affects work that is being carried out by one or more members of the registered employee organisation or relates to or affects any of those members;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s87/1/b.content: the suspected contravention relates to or affects work that is being carried out by one or more persons whose employment is subject to a collective agreement, a certified agreement or an enterprise agreement, or relates to or affects any of those persons, and that agreement applies to the registered employee organisation;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s87/1/c.content: the suspected contravention relates to or affects work that is being carried out by one or more persons— (i) who are eligible to be members of the registered employee organisation; and (ii) whose employment is not subject to a collective agreement, a certified agreement or an enterprise agreement which applies to any registered employee organisation— or relates to or affects any of those persons. Note Place is defined in section 5 as including a car, truck, ship, boat, airplane and any other vehicle. substituted by No. 24/2009 s. 35(1). substituted by No. 24/2009 s. 35(1).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s87/2.content: The authorised representative may enter the place, Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 100 during working hours, for the purpose only of enquiring into the suspected contravention.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s87/3.content: Nothing in this section requires an authorised representative of a registered employee organisation to disclose to another person the names of persons who are members of that organisation.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s87/4.content: In this section— certified agreement means a pre-reform certified agreement that continues in existence as a transitional instrument under the Fair Work Transition Act; collective agreement means a workplace agreement that is a collective agreement that continues in existence as a transitional instrument under the Fair Work Transition Act; enterprise agreement means an enterprise agreement made under the Commonwealth Fair Work Act. Note Section 90 provides certain limitations on the exercise of the powers conferred by this section.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s88/1.content: Immediately on entering a place under section 87, an authorised representative of a registered employee organisation must take all reasonable steps to give a notice to and produce his or her entry permit for inspection by—

about the exercise of any of those powers, either

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s89/1.content: An authorised representative of a registered employee organisation who enters a place under section 87 may do any of the following but only to the extent that it is reasonable for the purpose of enquiring into the suspected contravention—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s89/1/a.content: inspect any plant, substance or other thing at the place;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s89/1/b.content: observe work carried on at the place;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s89/1/ba.content: take photographs or measurements or make sketches or recordings at the place;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s89/1/c.content: consult with one or more employees (with their consent) at the place who are members or are eligible to be members of the registered employee organisation;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s89/1/d.content: consult with any employer at the place about anything relevant to the matter into which the representative is enquiring.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s89/2.content: The authorised representative must produce his or her entry permit for inspection if asked to do so when exercising any of the powers under subsection (1).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s89/3.content: If, while the authorised representative is at the place, an issue arises between the authorised representative and the employer who has, or a person who on behalf of the employer has, the management and control of the work at the place inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 30.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s89/4.content: The Authority must ensure that an inspector Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 102 about the exercise of any of those powers, either of those persons may ask the Authority to arrange for an inspector to attend at the place to enquire into the issue. attends the place as soon as possible after the request is made and the inspector—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s89/4/a.content: must as soon as possible enquire into the issue; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s89/4/b.content: may perform any of his or her functions or exercise any of his or her powers under this Act that the inspector considers reasonably necessary in the circumstances.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s90/1.content: Despite anything else in this Part, an authorised representative of a registered employee organisation is not entitled to exercise a power under this Part in respect of—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s90/1/a.content: any part of a place that is used for residential purposes except with the consent of the occupier for the time being of the place; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s90/1/b.content: any part of a place to which access is limited to any extent, by or under another Act, to particular persons or circumstances the effect of which is that the authorised representative is precluded from entering the part of the place.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s90/2.content: Despite anything else in this Part but subject to subsection (3), an authorised representative of a registered employee organisation is not entitled to exercise a power under this Part in respect of a place, except with the consent of the employer who has, or a person who on behalf of the employer has, the management and control of the work, if the exercise of that power would cause any work at the place to cease.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s90/3.content: Nothing in subsection (2) prevents an authorised Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 103 representative who reasonably believes that there is an immediate and significant risk of serious injury or death to one or more employees from warning the employee or employees of that risk.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s90/4.content: To avoid doubt, nothing in subsection (2) prevents an authorised representative from consulting with an employee during his or her meal-time or other breaks.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s91.title: Offences by authorised representatives
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s91.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
104

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s91/a.content: intentionally and unreasonably hinder or An authorised representative must not— obstruct any employer or employee; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s91/b.content: intentionally intimidate or threaten any employer or employee; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s91/c.content: intentionally use or disclose, for a purpose not reasonably connected with the exercise of a power under this Part, information that was acquired from any employer or employee; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s91/ca.content: intentionally use, disclose or provide to another person, for a purpose not reasonably connected with the exercise of a power under this Part, photographs or measurements taken or sketches or recordings made in the exercise of a power under section 89(1)(ba); or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s91/d.content: intentionally exercise or purport to exercise a power under this Part other than for the purpose of enquiring into a suspected contravention of this Act or the regulations. Penalty: 60 penalty units. inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 31.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s92.title: Loss or damage caused by authorised representative
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s92.content:
(1) If an authorised representative of a registered 
employee organisation is convicted or found 
guilty of an offence against section 91, a person 
who suffers significant loss or damage as a result 
of the commission of the offence is entitled to 
recover from that organisation, by action in a 
court of competent jurisdiction, an amount in 
respect of that loss or damage. 
 (2) A court may make an order in proceedings under 
subsection (1) for the payment of an amount that 
the court considers reasonable in the 
circumstances.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s92/1.content: If an authorised representative of a registered employee organisation is convicted or found guilty of an offence against section 91, a person who suffers significant loss or damage as a result of the commission of the offence is entitled to recover from that organisation, by action in a court of competent jurisdiction, an amount in respect of that loss or damage.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s92/2.content: A court may make an order in proceedings under subsection (1) for the payment of an amount that the court considers reasonable in the circumstances.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s93.title: Offence to obstruct etc. authorised representative
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s93.content:
A person must not— 
 (a) refuse an authorised representative entry to a 
workplace; or 
 (b) intentionally hinder, obstruct, intimidate or 
threaten an authorised representative in the 
exercise of his or her powers under this Part, 
or induce or attempt to induce any other 
person to do so. 
Penalty: 60 penalty units for a natural person; 
300 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s93/a.content: refuse an authorised representative entry to a A person must not— workplace; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s93/b.content: intentionally hinder, obstruct, intimidate or threaten an authorised representative in the exercise of his or her powers under this Part, or induce or attempt to induce any other person to do so. Penalty: 60 penalty units for a natural person; 300 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s94/b.content: an authorised representative of a registered employee organisation. Penalty: 60 penalty units.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s95.title: Appointment of inspectors
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s95.content:

106

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s95/1.content: The Authority may, by instrument in writing—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s95/1/a.content: appoint an officer or employee of the Authority to be an inspector for the purposes of this Act; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s95/1/b.content: appoint a person employed under Part 3 of the Public Administration Act 2004 by the Department Head (within the meaning of that Act) of the Department of Primary Industries to be an inspector for the purposes of this Act in respect of activities carried out under the Petroleum Act 1998 or the Mineral Resources (Sustainable Development) Act 1990.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s95/2.content: The appointment of a person as an inspector for the purposes of this Act and either or both of the following Acts may be made by a single instrument—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s95/3.content: The Authority must give each inspector a certificate of appointment signed by the chief executive of the Authority (appointed under section 498 of the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s95/4.content: A certificate of appointment given to an inspector in accordance with subsection (3) is conclusive proof of the valid appointment of the inspector under this section. amended by Nos 63/2006 s. 61(Sch. item 26.2), 6/2009 s. 56. amended by No. 67/2013 s. 649(Sch. 9 item 25(5)).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s96/1.content: The Authority must issue an identity card to each inspector containing a photograph of the inspector and his or her signature.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s96/2.content: An inspector must produce his or her identity card for inspection if asked to do so when performing a function or exercising a power under this Act or the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s96/3.content: If a person to whom an identity card has been issued ceases to be an inspector, the person must return the identity card to the Authority as soon as practicable.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s97.title: Inspectors subject to Authority's directions
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s97.content:

 (2) A direction under subsection (1) may be of a 
general nature or may relate to a specified matter 
or specified class of matter.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s97/2.content: A direction under subsection (1) may be of a general nature or may relate to a specified matter or specified class of matter.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s99/a.content: inspect, examine and make enquiries at the An inspector who enters a place under this Division may do any of the following— place;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s99/b.content: inspect and examine any thing (including a document) at the place;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s99/c.content: bring any equipment or materials to the place that may be required;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s99/d.content: seize any thing (including a document) at the place that may afford evidence of the commission of an offence against this Act or the regulations;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s99/e.content: seize any thing at the place for further examination or testing but only if the inspector reasonably believes that the examination or testing is reasonably necessary and cannot be reasonably conducted on site;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s99/f.content: take photographs or measurements or make sketches or recordings;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s99/g.content: exercise any other power conferred on the inspector by this Act or the regulations;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s99/h.content: do any other thing that is reasonably Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 108 necessary for the purpose of the inspector performing his or her functions or exercising his or her powers under this Act or the regulations. Note The powers conferred by this section are limited if all or part of the place is used only for residential purposes (see section 107).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s100/1.content: An inspector who enters a place under this answers to questions Division may do any or all of the following—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s100/1/a.content: require a person to produce a document or part of a document; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s100/1/b.content: examine that document or part; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s100/1/c.content: require a person at the place to answer any questions put by the inspector.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s100/b.content: must inform the person that he or she may Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 109 requirement, without reasonable excuse, is an offence; and refuse or fail to answer any question if answering the question would tend to incriminate him or her.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s100/5.content: Despite section 7 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009, a proceeding for an offence against this section must be commenced within 12 months after the date on which the Authority becomes aware that an offence has been committed.

and mark and seal or fasten up each part in a

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s101/1.content: An inspector who enters a place under this Division may take (without payment) samples of any thing at the place that may be required for analysis.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s101/2.content: If an inspector intends to take a sample, he or she must notify the following persons of his or her intention—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s101/2/a.content: the occupier or apparent occupier for the time being of the place; and Note 2 to s. 100(4) amended by No. 69/2009 s. 54(Sch. Pt 1 item 40.1). inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 18(4).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s101/b.content: if members of a designated work group are Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 110 affected in any way by the taking of the sample, a health and safety representative for that group.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s101/3.content: Unless it is unsafe to do so, after taking the sample the inspector must—

 (2) However, an inspector is not required to notify, or

delay; or

has entered the place or was notified in 
advance of when he or she would enter.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s102/1.content: Immediately on entering a place under Division 3, an inspector must take all reasonable steps to notify the following persons of the entry and to produce his or her identity card for inspection by those persons—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s102/1/a.content: the occupier or apparent occupier for the time being of the place;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s102/1/b.content: if members of a designated work group are affected in any way by the entry, a health and safety representative for the designated work group.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s102/2.content: However, an inspector is not required to notify, or Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 111 produce his or her identity card for inspection by, a person if—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s102/2/b.content: the person is already aware that the inspector has entered the place or was notified in advance of when he or she would enter.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103.title: Report to be given about entry
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
112   
 (3) If the inspector takes photographs or makes 
sketches or recordings under section 99(f), the 
report must also include a statement that— 
 (a) the photographs have been taken or sketches 
or recordings have been made; and 
 (b) they are or will be available for inspection at 
a specified place. 
 (4) The report may be given in a manner specified in 
section 115(1) or (1A).  
 (5) Section 8(1) and (2) of the Electronic 
Transactions (Victoria) Act 2000 do not apply to 
the giving of a report by electronic 
communication in a manner specified in section 
115(1) or (1A).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/1.content: An inspector who enters a place under Division 3 must give a report concerning the entry when, or as soon as practicable after, the inspector leaves the place to—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/1/a.content: the occupier or apparent occupier for the time being of the place; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/1/b.content: if members of a designated work group work at the workplace, a health and safety representative for the designated work group.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/2.content: The report must be in writing and include—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/2/a.content: the time of the entry and departure; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/2/b.content: the purpose of the entry; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/2/c.content: a description of things done while at the place; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/2/d.content: a summary of the inspector's observations while at the place; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/2/e.content: the procedure for contacting the Authority and the inspector for further details of the entry; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/2/f.content: the procedure for seeking review of any decision made by the inspector during the entry.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/3.content: If the inspector takes photographs or makes Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 112 sketches or recordings under section 99(f), the report must also include a statement that—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/3/a.content: the photographs have been taken or sketches or recordings have been made; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/3/b.content: they are or will be available for inspection at a specified place.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/4.content: The report may be given in a manner specified in section 115(1) or (1A).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s103/5.content: Section 8(1) and (2) of the Electronic Transactions (Victoria) Act 2000 do not apply to the giving of a report by electronic communication in a manner specified in section 115(1) or (1A).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104.title: Issue of search warrants
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
113   
 (3) The search warrant may authorise a named 
inspector and any assistants the inspector 
considers necessary— 
 (a) to enter the place or part of the place named 
or described in the warrant; and 
 (b) to search for the thing named or described in 
the warrant. 
 (4) In addition to any other requirement, the search 
warrant must state— 
 (a) the offence suspected; and 
 (b) the place to be searched; and 
 (c) a description of the thing for which the 
search is to be made; and 
 (d) any conditions to which the warrant is 
subject; and 
 (e) whether entry is authorised to be made at any 
time or during specified hours; and 
 (f) that the warrant authorises entry on only one 
occasion; and 
 (g) a day, not later than 7 days after the warrant 
is issued, on which it ceases to have effect. 
 (5) A search warrant must be issued in accordance 
with the Magistrates' Court Act 1989 and in the 
form prescribed under that Act. 
 (6) The rules that apply to search warrants mentioned 
in the Magistrates' Court Act 1989 extend and 
apply to search warrants under this section.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/1.content: An inspector may apply to a magistrate for the issue of a search warrant in relation to a particular place if the inspector believes on reasonable grounds that there is, or may be within the next 72 hours, a particular thing (including a document) at the place that may afford evidence of the commission of an offence against this Act or the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/2.content: A magistrate may issue the search warrant if he or she is satisfied by evidence on oath or by affirmation, whether oral or by affidavit, that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that there is, or may be within 72 hours, a particular thing (including a document) at the place that may afford evidence of the commission of an offence against this Act or the regulations. inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 17. inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 17. amended by No. 6/2018 s. 68(Sch. 2 item 91).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/3.content: The search warrant may authorise a named Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 113 inspector and any assistants the inspector considers necessary—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/3/a.content: to enter the place or part of the place named or described in the warrant; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/3/b.content: to search for the thing named or described in the warrant.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/4.content: In addition to any other requirement, the search warrant must state—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/4/b.content: the place to be searched; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/4/c.content: a description of the thing for which the search is to be made; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/4/d.content: any conditions to which the warrant is subject; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/4/e.content: whether entry is authorised to be made at any time or during specified hours; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/4/f.content: that the warrant authorises entry on only one occasion; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/4/g.content: a day, not later than 7 days after the warrant is issued, on which it ceases to have effect.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/5.content: A search warrant must be issued in accordance with the Magistrates' Court Act 1989 and in the form prescribed under that Act.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s104/6.content: The rules that apply to search warrants mentioned in the Magistrates' Court Act 1989 extend and apply to search warrants under this section.

 (a) announce that he or she is authorised by the

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s105/1.content: Before executing a search warrant, the inspector named in the warrant or an assistant to the inspector must—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s105/a.content: announce that he or she is authorised by the Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 114 warrant to enter the place; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s105/b.content: give any person at the place an opportunity to allow that entry.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s105/2.content: However, the inspector or an assistant to the inspector need not comply with subsection (1) if he or she believes on reasonable grounds that immediate entry to the place is needed to ensure—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s105/2/a.content: the safety of any person; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s105/2/b.content: that the effective execution of the warrant is not frustrated.
