/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108.title: Return of seized things
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
116   
 (4) To avoid doubt, the Authority may destroy or 
dispose of a thing without giving notice to any 
person of the destruction or disposal if— 
 (a) the thing is forfeited to the Authority under 
section 109; or 
 (b) the owner of the thing has notified the 
Authority under subsection (1)(ba) that the 
owner transfers ownership of the thing to the 
Authority; or 
 (c) the thing is a copy made under section 124 of 
a document or part of a document; or 
 (d) the Authority is otherwise authorised (by a 
law or court order) to destroy or dispose of 
the thing without giving notice to any 
person.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/1.content: As soon as possible after an inspector seizes any thing (including a document) under this Part the Authority must return the thing to the owner unless—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/1/a.content: the Authority considers it necessary to retain the thing because it may afford evidence in proceedings, that have been or may be commenced, for an offence against this Act or the regulations; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/1/b.content: the thing is forfeited to the Authority under section 109; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/1/ba.content: the owner of the thing notifies the Authority in writing that the owner transfers ownership of the thing to the Authority; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/1/bb.content: the thing is a copy made under section 124 of a document or part of a document; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/1/c.content: the Authority is otherwise authorised (by a law or court order) to retain, destroy or dispose of the thing.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/2.content: The thing may be returned either unconditionally or on such terms and conditions as the Authority considers appropriate to eliminate or reduce any risks to health or safety.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/3.content: If the Authority imposes terms or conditions on the return of a thing, the owner must comply with each of those terms and conditions. Penalty: 60 penalty units for a natural person; 300 penalty units for a body corporate. inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 32(1). inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 32(1).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/4.content: To avoid doubt, the Authority may destroy or Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 116 dispose of a thing without giving notice to any person of the destruction or disposal if—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/4/a.content: the thing is forfeited to the Authority under section 109; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/4/b.content: the owner of the thing has notified the Authority under subsection (1)(ba) that the owner transfers ownership of the thing to the Authority; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/4/c.content: the thing is a copy made under section 124 of a document or part of a document; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s108/4/d.content: the Authority is otherwise authorised (by a law or court order) to destroy or dispose of the thing without giving notice to any person.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s109.title: Forfeiture of seized things
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s109.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
117

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s109/1.content: Any thing (including a document) that an inspector has seized and retained under this Part is forfeited to the Authority if the Authority—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s109/1/a.content: cannot find its owner despite making reasonable enquiries; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s109/1/b.content: cannot return it to the owner despite making reasonable efforts; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s109/1/c.content: considers it necessary to retain the thing to prevent the commission of an offence against this Act or the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s109/2.content: If a thing is forfeited to the Authority under subsection (1)(c), the Authority must notify (in writing) the owner accordingly, setting out how the owner may seek review of the decision to forfeit the thing, unless the Authority cannot find the owner despite making reasonable enquiries. inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 32(2).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110.title: Power to issue non-disturbance notice
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
118   
 (3) If an inspector considers it necessary to do so, he 
or she may issue one or more subsequent 
non-disturbance notices to a person, whether 
before or after the expiry of the previous notice, 
each of which must comply with subsection (2). 
 (4) A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to 
comply with a non-disturbance notice issued to 
the person is guilty of an indictable offence and 
liable to a fine not exceeding— 
 (a) in the case of a natural person, 500 penalty 
units; or 
 (b) in the case of a body corporate, 2500 penalty 
units. 
Note 
However, the offence may be heard and determined 
summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 
2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/1.content: An inspector who has entered a place under this Part may issue a non-disturbance notice to a person who is or appears to be the occupier for the time being of the place requiring the person to—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/1/a.content: stop the use or movement of, or interference with, any specified plant, substance or other thing at the place; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/1/b.content: prevent the disturbance of the specified plant, substance or other thing or a specified area of the place where the plant, substance or other thing is located— if the inspector reasonably believes that it is necessary to do so to facilitate the performance of his or her functions or exercise of his or her powers under this Act or the regulations in relation to the place or any plant, substance or other thing at the place.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/2.content: A non-disturbance notice must specify the period (of no more than 7 days) for which it applies and set out—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/2/a.content: the obligations of the person to whom the notice is issued; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/2/b.content: the penalty for contravening the notice; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/2/c.content: how the person may seek review of the issue of the notice; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/2/d.content: a statement of the effect of section 117 (proceedings for offences not affected by notices).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/3.content: If an inspector considers it necessary to do so, he Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 118 or she may issue one or more subsequent non-disturbance notices to a person, whether before or after the expiry of the previous notice, each of which must comply with subsection (2).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/4.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a non-disturbance notice issued to the person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to a fine not exceeding—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/4/a.content: in the case of a natural person, 500 penalty units; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s110/4/b.content: in the case of a body corporate, 2500 penalty units. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111.title: Power to issue improvement notice
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
120   
 (b) interim directions, or interim conditions on 
the carrying on of any activities to which the 
notice relates, that the inspector considers 
necessary to minimise risks to the health or 
safety of a person. 
 (4) A person to whom an improvement notice is 
issued must comply with the notice. 
Penalty: 500 penalty units for a natural person; 
2500 penalty units for a body corporate. 
 (5) An offence against subsection (4) is an indictable 
offence. 
Note 
However, the offence may be heard and determined 
summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 
2009). 
 (6) If an application for review of a decision under 
this section has been made under Part 10, an 
inspector must not give a certificate under 
subsection (3)(a) in relation to the improvement 
notice concerned until after the review ends.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/1.content: If an inspector reasonably believes that a person—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/1/a.content: is contravening a provision of this Act or the regulations; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/1/b.content: has contravened such a provision in circumstances that make it likely that the contravention will continue or be repeated— the inspector may issue to the person an improvement notice requiring the person to remedy the contravention or likely contravention or the matters or activities causing the contravention or likely contravention.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/2/a.content: state the basis for the inspector's belief on which the issue of the notice is based; and Note to s. 110(4) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.21).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/b.content: interim directions, or interim conditions on Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 120 the carrying on of any activities to which the notice relates, that the inspector considers necessary to minimise risks to the health or safety of a person.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/c.content: specify a date (with or without a time) by which the person is required to remedy the contravention or likely contravention or the matters or activities causing the contravention or likely contravention, that the inspector considers is reasonable having regard to the severity of the risk to the health or safety of any person and the nature of the contravention or likely contravention; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/d.content: set out the penalty for contravening the notice; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/e.content: state how the person may seek review of the issue of the notice; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/f.content: include a statement of the effect of section 117 (proceedings for offences not affected by notices).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/3.content: An improvement notice may include directions concerning the measures to be taken to remedy the contravention or likely contravention, or the matters or activities causing the contravention or likely contravention, to which the notice relates and may, in particular, include—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/3/a.content: a direction that if the person has not remedied the contravention, likely contravention, matters or activities (as the case may be) by the date and time (if any) specified in the notice, an activity to which the notice relates is to cease until an inspector has certified in writing that the contravention, likely contravention, matters or activities have been remedied; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/4.content: A person to whom an improvement notice is issued must comply with the notice. Penalty: 500 penalty units for a natural person; 2500 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/5.content: An offence against subsection (4) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s111/6.content: If an application for review of a decision under this section has been made under Part 10, an inspector must not give a certificate under subsection (3)(a) in relation to the improvement notice concerned until after the review ends.

122   
contravention or likely contravention mentioned

this section has been made under Part 10, an

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/1.content: If an inspector reasonably believes that—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/1/a.content: an activity is occurring at a workplace that involves or will involve a serious risk to the health or safety of a person emanating from an immediate or imminent exposure to a hazard; or Note to s. 111(5) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.22). amended by No. 10/2022 s. 49.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/b.content: an activity may occur at a workplace that, if Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 121 it occurs, will involve a serious risk to the health or safety of a person emanating from an immediate or imminent exposure to a hazard— the inspector may issue to a person who has or appears to have control over the activity a prohibition notice prohibiting the carrying on of the activity, or the carrying on of the activity in a specified way, until an inspector has certified in writing that the matters that give or will give rise to the risk have been remedied.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/2/a.content: state the basis for the inspector's belief on which the issue of the notice is based; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/2/b.content: specify the activity which the inspector believes involves or will involve the risk and the matters which give or will give rise to the risk; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/2/c.content: if the inspector believes that the activity involves a contravention or likely contravention of a provision of this Act or the regulations, specify that provision and state the basis for that belief; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/2/d.content: set out the penalty for contravening the notice; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/2/e.content: state how the person may seek review of the issue of the notice; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/2/f.content: include a statement of the effect of section 117 (proceedings for offences not affected by notices).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/3.content: A prohibition notice may include directions on the measures to be taken to remedy the risk, activities or matters to which the notice relates, or the amended by No. 10/2022 s. 49.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/4.content: A prohibition notice that prohibits the carrying on Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 122 contravention or likely contravention mentioned in subsection (2)(c). of an activity in a specified way may do so by specifying one or more of the following—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/4/a.content: a workplace, or part of a workplace, at which the activity is not to be carried out;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/4/b.content: any thing that is not to be used in connection with the activity;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/4/c.content: any procedure that is not to be followed in connection with the activity.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/5.content: A person to whom a prohibition notice is issued must comply with the notice. Penalty: 500 penalty units for a natural person; 2500 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/6.content: An offence against subsection (5) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s112/7.content: If an application for review of a decision under this section has been made under Part 10, an inspector must not give a certificate under subsection (1) in relation to the prohibition notice concerned until after the review ends.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s113.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
123   
 (b) offer the person to whom it is issued a choice 
of ways in which to remedy the 
contravention, likely contravention, matters 
or activities concerned.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s113/a.content: refer to a compliance code; and A direction or condition included in an improvement notice or prohibition notice may— Note to s. 112(6) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.23).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s113/b.content: offer the person to whom it is issued a choice Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 123 of ways in which to remedy the contravention, likely contravention, matters or activities concerned.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s114.title: Variation or cancellation of notices
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s114.content:
A non-disturbance notice, improvement notice or 
prohibition notice issued by an inspector may only 
be varied or cancelled by the Authority. 
Note 
The Authority may vary or cancel such a notice in the same 
way that an inspector may make the notice (see section 41A 
of the Interpretation of Legislation Act 1984).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115.title: Issue of notices
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
125   
 (b) if the person is not an employee or is an 
employer who is given a copy of the notice 
in accordance with paragraph (a)— 
 (i) bring the notice to the attention of each 
other person whose work is affected by 
the notice; and 
 (ii) give a copy of the notice to each health 
and safety representative who 
represents employees whose work is 
affected by the notice; and 
 (iii) display a copy of the notice in a 
prominent place at or near the 
workplace, or part of the workplace, at 
which work is being performed that is 
affected by the notice. 
Penalty: 5 penalty units for a natural person; 
25 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115/1.content: A non-disturbance notice, improvement notice or prohibition notice may be issued to a person by—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115/1/a.content: delivering it personally to the person or sending it by post or facsimile to the person's usual or last known place of residence or business; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115/1/b.content: leaving it for the person at the person's usual or last known place of residence or business with a person who is apparently over 16 years and who apparently resides or works there; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115/1/c.content: leaving it for the person at the workplace to which the notice relates with a person who is apparently over 16 years and who apparently is the occupier for the time being of the workplace; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115/1/d.content: if the person to whom the notice is to be issued is not a body corporate, sending it by electronic communication to the person at the person's usual or last known electronic address; or (Heading) amended by No. 36/2021 s. 18(1). amended by No. 48/2017 s. 19(1). inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 19(2), amended by No. 36/2021 s. 18(2).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115/e.content: if the person is an employer registered Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 124 under section 434 of the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013, sending it by post or electronic communication to the last address for service shown on a communication from the employer to the Authority. (1A) In addition to subsection (1), if the person to whom a notice is to be issued is a body corporate, the notice may be issued by—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115/a.content: delivering it personally to the head office, registered office or principal place of business of the body corporate; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115/b.content: if the person is not an employee or is an Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 125 employer who is given a copy of the notice in accordance with paragraph (a)— (i) bring the notice to the attention of each other person whose work is affected by the notice; and (ii) give a copy of the notice to each health and safety representative who represents employees whose work is affected by the notice; and (iii) display a copy of the notice in a prominent place at or near the workplace, or part of the workplace, at which work is being performed that is affected by the notice. Penalty: 5 penalty units for a natural person; 25 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115/c.content: sending it by electronic communication to an employee, agent or officer of the body corporate. (1B) Subject to subsection (1C), this section is in addition to, and not in derogation from, the Interpretation of Legislation Act 1984, the Electronic Transactions (Victoria) Act 2000 and sections 109X and 601CX of the Corporations Act. (1C) Section 8(1) and (2) of the Electronic Transactions (Victoria) Act 2000 do not apply to the issue of a notice by electronic communication under this section.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115/2.content: A person to whom a non-disturbance notice, improvement notice or prohibition notice is issued must as soon as possible—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s115/2/a.content: if the person is an employee, give a copy of the notice to his or her employer; or inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 19(2). inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 19(3), substituted by No. 36/2021 s. 18(3). inserted by No. 48/2017 s. 19(3), amended by No. 49/2018 s. 21(1). inserted by No. 49/2018 s. 21(2), amended by No. 36/2021 s. 18(4).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s116.title: Formal irregularities or defects in notices
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s116.content:
A non-disturbance notice, improvement notice or 
prohibition notice is not invalid merely because 
of— 
 (a) a formal defect or irregularity in the notice 
unless the defect or irregularity causes or is 
likely to cause substantial injustice; or 
 (b) a failure to use the correct name of the 
person to whom the notice is issued if the 
notice sufficiently identifies the person and 
is issued to the person in accordance with 
section 115.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s116/a.content: a formal defect or irregularity in the notice A non-disturbance notice, improvement notice or prohibition notice is not invalid merely because of— unless the defect or irregularity causes or is likely to cause substantial injustice; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s116/b.content: a failure to use the correct name of the person to whom the notice is issued if the notice sufficiently identifies the person and is issued to the person in accordance with section 115.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s117.title: Proceedings for offences not affected by notices
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s117.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
126   
in connection with any matter in respect of which 
the notice was issued.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s118.title: Injunctions for non-compliance with notices
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s118.content:
(1) The Authority may apply to the Supreme Court 
for an injunction— 
 (a) compelling a person to comply with a 
non-disturbance notice, improvement notice 
or prohibition notice; or 
 (b) restraining a person from contravening such 
a notice. 
 (2) The Authority may do so whether or not 
proceedings have been instituted for an offence 
against this Act or the regulations in connection 
with any matter in respect of which the notice was 
issued.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s118/1.content: The Authority may apply to the Supreme Court for an injunction—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s118/1/a.content: compelling a person to comply with a non-disturbance notice, improvement notice or prohibition notice; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s118/1/b.content: restraining a person from contravening such a notice.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s118/2.content: The Authority may do so whether or not proceedings have been instituted for an offence against this Act or the regulations in connection with any matter in respect of which the notice was issued.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s119.title: Power to require name and address
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s119.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
127   
 (3) A person who, in response to being asked to state 
his or her name and address in accordance with 
this section— 
 (a) refuses or fails to do so; or 
 (b) states a name that is false in a material 
particular; or 
 (c) states an address other than the full and 
correct address of his or her ordinary place 
of residence or business— 
is guilty of an offence and liable to a fine not 
exceeding 5 penalty units. 
 (4) A person who is asked to state his or her name and 
address may ask the inspector to produce his or 
her identity card for inspection.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s119/1.content: An inspector may ask a person to state his or her name and address if the inspector reasonably believes that the person—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s119/1/a.content: may be able to assist in the investigation of an indictable offence under this Act that has been committed or is suspected of having been committed; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s119/1/b.content: has committed or is about to commit an offence (whether indictable or summary) under this Act or the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s119/2.content: The inspector must inform the person of the grounds for his or her belief in sufficient detail to allow the person to understand the nature of the offence or suspected offence.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s119/3.content: A person who, in response to being asked to state Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 127 his or her name and address in accordance with this section—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s119/3/a.content: refuses or fails to do so; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s119/3/b.content: states a name that is false in a material particular; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s119/3/c.content: states an address other than the full and correct address of his or her ordinary place of residence or business— is guilty of an offence and liable to a fine not exceeding 5 penalty units.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s119/4.content: A person who is asked to state his or her name and address may ask the inspector to produce his or her identity card for inspection.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s120.title: Power to give directions
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s120.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
128

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s120/1.content: An inspector may give a direction (either orally or in writing) to a person at a workplace if the inspector reasonably believes that it is necessary to do so because of a serious risk to the health or safety of any person emanating from an immediate or imminent exposure to a hazard.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s120/2.content: A person must not, without reasonable excuse, refuse or fail to comply with a direction given to the person under subsection (1). Penalty: 500 penalty units for a natural person; 2500 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s120/3.content: An offence against subsection (2) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009). amended by No. 10/2022 s. 50. Note to s. 120(3) amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.24).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s121.title: Persons who must assist inspector
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s121.content:
The following persons must not, without 
reasonable excuse, refuse or fail to provide such 
assistance as an inspector may reasonably require 
for the performance of his or her functions or 
exercise of his or her powers under this Act or the 
regulations— 
 (a) an occupier or apparent occupier for the time 
being of a workplace; 
 (b) an employer who has the management and 
control of a workplace; 
 (c) an employee at a workplace. 
Penalty: 60 penalty units for a natural person; 
300 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s121/a.content: an occupier or apparent occupier for the time The following persons must not, without reasonable excuse, refuse or fail to provide such assistance as an inspector may reasonably require for the performance of his or her functions or exercise of his or her powers under this Act or the regulations— being of a workplace;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s121/b.content: an employer who has the management and control of a workplace;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s121/c.content: an employee at a workplace. Penalty: 60 penalty units for a natural person; 300 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s122.title: Other assistance in exercising powers
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s122.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
129   
 (3) If an inspector uses the assistance of an 
interpreter— 
 (a) any enquiry or request made by the 
interpreter on the inspector's behalf is taken 
to have been made by the inspector; and 
 (b) any answer given to the interpreter is taken 
to have been given to the inspector.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s122/1.content: For the purpose of exercising a power under this Act or the regulations, an inspector may seek the assistance of any person.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s122/2.content: If the power being exercised involves entry to a workplace, the person assisting must be allowed access to that workplace by—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s122/2/a.content: the occupier or apparent occupier for the time being of the workplace; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s122/2/b.content: the employer who has the management and control of the workplace. Penalty: 60 penalty units for a natural person; 300 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s122/3.content: If an inspector uses the assistance of an Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 129 interpreter—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s122/3/a.content: any enquiry or request made by the interpreter on the inspector's behalf is taken to have been made by the inspector; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s122/3/b.content: any answer given to the interpreter is taken to have been given to the inspector.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s123.title: Inspector may take affidavits
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s123.content:
An inspector is authorised to take affidavits for 
any purpose relating or incidental to the 
performance of his or her functions or exercise of 
his or her powers under this Act or the 
regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s124.title: Inspector may copy documents
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s124.content:
An inspector may make copies of, or take extracts 
from, a document or part of a document given to 
the inspector in accordance with a requirement 
under this Act or the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s125.title: Offences in relation to inspections
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s125.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
130   
Penalty: 60 penalty units for a natural person; 
300 penalty units for a body corporate. 
 (2) A person must not assault, directly or indirectly 
intimidate or threaten, or attempt to intimidate or 
threaten, an inspector or a person assisting an 
inspector. 
Penalty: Imprisonment for 2 years, or 
240 penalty units, or both for a natural 
person; 
1200 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s125/1/a.content: intentionally hinder or obstruct an inspector in the performance of his or her functions or exercise of his or her powers under this Act or the regulations, or induce or attempt to induce any other person to do so; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s125/1/b.content: intentionally conceal from an inspector the location or existence of any other person or any plant, substance or other thing; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s125/1/c.content: intentionally prevent or attempt to prevent any other person from assisting an inspector.

Penalty: Imprisonment for 2 years, or 240 penalty units, or both for a natural person; 1200 penalty units for a body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A.title: Establishment of Workplace Incidents Consultative
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
132   
 (ii) subject to subsection (5), the experience 
or qualifications of members; and 
 (iii) the terms and conditions on which 
members are appointed; and 
 (iv) the remuneration, allowances and 
expenses of members; and 
 (b) the procedure of the Committee. 
 (5) Regulations providing for the experience or 
qualifications of the members of the Committee 
must require that a majority of members be 
persons who have been affected, directly or 
indirectly, by incidents that— 
 (a) occur at a workplace; and 
 (b) involve death, serious injury or serious

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A/1.content: The Minister must, in accordance with the Committee regulations, establish a Workplace Incidents Consultative Committee.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A/2.content: The function of the Committee is to provide advice and make recommendations to the Minister about—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A/2/a.content: the needs of persons who are affected, directly or indirectly, by incidents that— (i) occur at a workplace; and (ii) involve death, serious injury or serious illness; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A/2/b.content: the development, review and improvement of policies, practices, strategies and systems relating to— (i) the incidents referred to in paragraph (a); or (ii) occupational health and safety more generally.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A/3.content: The Committee is to perform its function in accordance with the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A/4.content: Without limiting the generality of section 158, the regulations may make provision for or with respect to—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A/4/a.content: the appointment of members of the Committee, including— (i) the number of members; and Pt 9A (Heading and ss 126A, 126B) inserted by No. 50/2019 s. 4. S 126A inserted by No. 50/2019 s. 4.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A/b.content: the procedure of the Committee. Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 132 (ii) subject to subsection (5), the experience or qualifications of members; and (iii) the terms and conditions on which members are appointed; and (iv) the remuneration, allowances and expenses of members; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A/5.content: Regulations providing for the experience or qualifications of the members of the Committee must require that a majority of members be persons who have been affected, directly or indirectly, by incidents that—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126A/5/b.content: involve death, serious injury or serious illness.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126B.title: Annual report
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126B.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
133

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126B/1.content: The Workplace Incidents Consultative Committee established under section 126A may give the Minister a written report about the Committee's operations during a particular financial year.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s126B/2.content: On receiving a report under subsection (1), the Minister must cause the report to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 14 sitting days of that House. S 126B inserted by No. 50/2019 s. 4.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s127.title: Which decisions are reviewable
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s127.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
138

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s127/1/a.content: decisions made under this Act that are reviewable in accordance with this Part (reviewable decisions); and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s127/1/b.content: who is eligible to apply for review of a reviewable decision (the eligible person in relation to the reviewable decision).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s127/2.content: To avoid doubt, sections 4 and 5 of the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act 1998 apply for the purposes of this Act. Note Under section 4 of that Act, a person makes a decision if the person refuses to make a decision or an instrument, imposes a condition or restriction or does or refuses to do any other act or thing. Section 5 of that Act sets out when a person's interests are affected by a decision. Item Provision under which reviewable decision is made Eligible person in relation to reviewable decision 1. Section 45 (determination of unresolved particulars concerning designated work groups) (1) An employee whose interests are affected by the decision. (2) An employer whose interests are affected by the decision. 2. Section 54(4)(b) (appointment by an inspector of a person to conduct an election of a health and safety representative) (1) An employee whose interests are affected by the decision. (2) An employer whose interests are affected by the decision.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128.title: Internal review
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
139   
 (6) An application under this section does not affect 
the operation of the reviewable decision or 
prevent the taking of any action to implement it 
unless the Authority, on its own initiative or on 
the application of the applicant for review, stays 
the operation of the decision pending the 
determination of the review. 
 (7) The Authority must make a decision on an 
application for a stay within 24 hours after the 
making of the application. 
 (8) If the Authority has not made a decision in 
accordance with subsection (7), the Authority is 
taken to have made a decision to grant a stay. 
 (9) The Authority may attach any conditions to a stay 
of the operation of a reviewable decision that it 
considers appropriate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/1.content: An eligible person in relation to a reviewable decision, other than a decision made by the Authority, may apply to the Authority for review of the decision within—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/1/a.content: 14 days after the day on which the decision first came to the eligible person's notice; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/1/b.content: such longer period as the Authority allows.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/2.content: The application must be in the form approved (in writing) by the Authority.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/3.content: If an application is made to the Authority in accordance with this section, the Authority must make a decision—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/3/a.content: to affirm or vary the reviewable decision; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/3/b.content: to set aside the reviewable decision and substitute another decision that the Authority considers appropriate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/4.content: The Authority must give a written notice to the applicant setting out—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/4/a.content: the Authority's decision under subsection (3) and the reasons for the decision; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/4/b.content: the findings on material questions of fact that led to the decision, referring to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based— and, subject to section 128A, must do so within 14 days after the application is made or, if the reviewable decision was made under section 111(3)(a) or 112(1), within 7 days after the application is made.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/5.content: If the Authority has not notified an applicant of a decision in accordance with subsection (4), the Authority is taken to have made a decision to affirm the reviewable decision. amended by No. 10/2022 s. 51.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/6.content: An application under this section does not affect Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 139 the operation of the reviewable decision or prevent the taking of any action to implement it unless the Authority, on its own initiative or on the application of the applicant for review, stays the operation of the decision pending the determination of the review.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/7.content: The Authority must make a decision on an application for a stay within 24 hours after the making of the application.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/8.content: If the Authority has not made a decision in accordance with subsection (7), the Authority is taken to have made a decision to grant a stay.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128/9.content: The Authority may attach any conditions to a stay of the operation of a reviewable decision that it considers appropriate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128A.title: Requests for further information
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128A.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
140   
 (b) the period specified by the Authority in its 
most recent request has expired.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128A/1.content: The Authority may request an applicant under section 128 to provide further information in relation to the application.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128A/2/b.content: specify a period (not exceeding 7 days) during which the applicant may respond; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128A/2/c.content: indicate that, if the applicant does not provide the information within the specified period, the Authority may make a decision on the application without that information.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s128A/3.content: If the Authority requests further information under subsection (1), the period referred to in section 128(4) is suspended until the earlier of the following—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s129.content:

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s129/1.content: A person may apply to the Tribunal for review of—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s129/1/a.content: a reviewable decision made by the Authority; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s129/1/b.content: a decision made, or taken to have been made, by the Authority under section 128 in respect of a reviewable decision (including a decision concerning a stay of the operation of the reviewable decision)— if the person is an eligible person in relation to the reviewable decision.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s129/2/a.content: if the decision is to forfeit a thing (including a document) seized under Part 9, within 28 days after the day on which the decision first came to the applicant's notice; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s129/2/b.content: in the case of any other decision, within 14 days after the day on which the decision first came to the applicant's notice; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s129/2/c.content: if the Authority is required by the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act 1998 to give the applicant a statement of reasons, within 14 days after the day on which the applicant is given the statement— whichever period ends last.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s130.title: Proceedings may be brought by the Authority or
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s130.content:
inspectors 
 (1) Proceedings for an offence against this Act or the 
regulations may be brought only by— 
 (a) the Authority; or 
 (b) an inspector with the written authorisation of 
the Authority (either generally or in a 
particular case). 
 (2) An authorisation under subsection (1)(b) is 
sufficient authority to continue proceedings in any 
case where the court amends the charge-sheet, 
warrant or summons. 
 (3) An inspector who brings proceedings may 
conduct the proceedings before the court. 
 (4) The Authority must issue, and publish in the 
Government Gazette, general guidelines for 
or with respect to the prosecution of offences 
under this Act or the regulations. 
 (5) Nothing in this section affects the ability of 
the Director of Public Prosecutions to bring 
proceedings for an indictable offence against 
this Act or the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s130/1.content: Proceedings for an offence against this Act or the inspectors regulations may be brought only by—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s130/1/b.content: an inspector with the written authorisation of the Authority (either generally or in a particular case).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s130/2.content: An authorisation under subsection (1)(b) is sufficient authority to continue proceedings in any case where the court amends the charge-sheet, warrant or summons.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s130/3.content: An inspector who brings proceedings may conduct the proceedings before the court.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s130/4.content: The Authority must issue, and publish in the Government Gazette, general guidelines for or with respect to the prosecution of offences under this Act or the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s130/5.content: Nothing in this section affects the ability of the Director of Public Prosecutions to bring proceedings for an indictable offence against this Act or the regulations.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s131/6.content: The Authority must include in its annual report, and publish on its website, a statement setting out—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s132/1/a.content: within 2 years after the offence first comes to the notice of the Authority;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s132/1/b.content: within one year after a coronial report was made or a coronial inquiry or inquest ended, if it appeared from the report or the proceedings at the inquiry or inquest that an indictable offence had been committed against this Act;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s132/1/c.content: if an undertaking has been given under section 16 in relation to the offence, within 6 months after— (i) the undertaking is contravened; or (ii) it comes to the notice of the Authority that the undertaking has been contravened; or inserted by No. 49/2018 s. 22(4)(b). inserted by No. 49/2018 s. 22(5). substituted by No. 48/2017 s. 22. amended by No. 50/2019 s. 5(1).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s134.title: Evidence of certain matters
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s134.content:
In proceedings for an offence against this Act or

 (a) it is sufficient to allege that any place,

workplace within the meaning of this Act 
without further allegation; and 
 (b) if the age of a person is material and there is 
insufficient evidence of the person's actual 
age, the court may have regard to his or her 
apparent age.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s134/b.content: if the age of a person is material and there is insufficient evidence of the person's actual age, the court may have regard to his or her apparent age.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135.title: Adverse publicity orders
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
148   
 (6) The court must not make an adverse publicity 
order unless it is satisfied that the costs of 
complying with the order do not exceed the 
maximum penalty amount that the court may 
impose on the offender for the offence concerned. 
 (7) The court may make an adverse publicity order in 
relation to an offender in addition to or instead 
of— 
 (a) imposing a penalty on the offender; or 
 (b) making any other order that the court may 
make in relation to the offence.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/1.content: If a court convicts a person, or finds a person guilty, of an offence against this Act or the regulations the court may make an order (an adverse publicity order) in relation to the offender requiring the offender—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/1/a.content: to take either or both of the following actions within the period specified in the order— (i) to publicise, in the way specified in the order, the offence, its consequences, the penalty imposed and any other related matter; (ii) to notify a specified person or specified class of persons, in the way specified in the order, of the offence, its

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/b.content: to give the Authority, within 7 days after the Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 147 consequences, the penalty imposed and any other related matter; and end of the period specified in the order, evidence that the action or actions were taken by the offender in accordance with the order.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/2.content: The court may make an adverse publicity order on its own initiative or on the application of the prosecutor.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/3.content: If the offender fails to give evidence to the Authority in accordance with subsection (1)(b), the Authority, or a person authorised in writing by the Authority, may take the action or actions specified in the order.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/4/a.content: the offender gives evidence to the Authority in accordance with subsection (1)(b); and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/4/b.content: despite that evidence, the Authority is not satisfied that the offender has taken the action or actions specified in the order in accordance with the order— the Authority may apply to the court for an order authorising the Authority, or a person authorised in writing by the Authority, to take the action or actions.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/5.content: If the Authority or a person authorised in writing by the Authority takes an action or actions in accordance with subsection (3) or an order under subsection (4), the Authority is entitled to recover from the offender, by action in a court of competent jurisdiction, an amount in respect of the reasonable expenses of taking the action or actions as a debt due to the Authority.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/6.content: The court must not make an adverse publicity Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 148 order unless it is satisfied that the costs of complying with the order do not exceed the maximum penalty amount that the court may impose on the offender for the offence concerned.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/7.content: The court may make an adverse publicity order in relation to an offender in addition to or instead of—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/7/a.content: imposing a penalty on the offender; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s135/7/b.content: making any other order that the court may make in relation to the offence.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s136.title: Orders to undertake improvement projects
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s136.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
149

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s136/1.content: If a court convicts a person or finds a person guilty of an offence against this Act or the regulations the court may make an order requiring the offender to undertake a specified project for the general improvement of occupational health, safety and welfare within the period specified in the order.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s136/2.content: The order may specify conditions that must be complied with in undertaking the specified project.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s136/3.content: The court must not make an order under this section unless it is satisfied that the costs of complying with the order do not exceed the maximum penalty amount that the court may impose on the offender for the offence concerned.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s136/4.content: The court may make an order under this section in relation to an offender in addition to or instead of—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s136/4/a.content: imposing a penalty on the offender; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s136/4/b.content: making any other order that the court may make in relation to the offence.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137.title: Release on the giving of a health and safety
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
151

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/1.content: If a court convicts a person or finds a person undertaking guilty of an offence against this Act or the regulations the court may (with or without recording a conviction) adjourn the proceeding for a period of up to 2 years and make an order for the release of the offender on the offender giving an undertaking with specified conditions.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/2.content: An undertaking must specify the following conditions—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/2/a.content: that the offender attends before the court if called on to do so during the period of the adjournment and, if the court so specifies, at the time to which the further hearing is adjourned;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/2/b.content: that the offender does not commit, during the period of the adjournment, any offence against this Act, the regulations, the Equipment (Public Safety) Act 1994 or the Dangerous Goods Act 1985 or regulations made under those Acts;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/2/c.content: that the offender observes any special conditions imposed by the court.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/3.content: Without limiting subsection (2)(c), the court may impose on an offender who is an employer special conditions that the offender—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/3/a.content: engage a consultant, who is approved in writing by the Authority, to advise on or assist with occupational health and safety matters; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/3/b.content: develop and implement a systematic approach to managing risks to health or safety that arise or may arise in the conduct of the offender's undertaking; and amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.26). amended by Nos 66/2008 s. 32(2), 48/2017 s. 23.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/c.content: arrange for the carrying out of an audit of the Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 150 offender's undertaking in relation to health and safety by an independent person who is approved in writing by the Authority.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/4.content: An offender who has given an undertaking under this section may be called on to attend before the court—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/4/a.content: by order of the court; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/4/b.content: by notice issued by the proper officer (within the meaning of section 72(4) of the Sentencing Act 1991) of the court.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/5.content: An order or notice under subsection (4) must be served on the offender not less than 4 days before the time specified in it for the attendance.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/6.content: If the court is satisfied at the time to which a further hearing of a proceeding is adjourned that the offender has observed the conditions of the undertaking, it must discharge the offender without any further hearing of the proceeding.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/7.content: The court may make an order under this section in relation to an offender in addition to or instead of—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/7/a.content: imposing a penalty on the offender; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s137/7/b.content: making any other order that the court may make in relation to the offence. amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.27). amended by No. 68/2009 s. 97(Sch. item 90.28).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s139.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004

153

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s139/1.content: The regulations may provide that a person may be served with an infringement notice as an alternative to a prosecution for an offence (other than an indictable offence) against this Act or the regulations that is prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this section. (Heading) amended by No. 65/2011 s. 107(Sch. item 10.1). amended by Nos 65/2011 s. 107(Sch. items 10.2, 10.3), 32/2013 s. 44, 21/2015 s. 3(Sch. 1 item 36). inserted by No. 65/2011 s. 107(Sch. item 10.4). amended by No. 65/2011 s. 107(Sch. item 10.5).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s139/2.content: An infringement notice must specify a penalty for Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 152 (1A) An offence referred to in subsection (1) for which an infringement notice may be served is an infringement offence within the meaning of the Infringements Act 2006. (1B) For the purposes of subsection (1), an infringement notice for an offence referred to in subsection (1) may be served in a manner specified in section 115(1) or (1A). /au-victoria/ohs/2004/s139/4.content: Despite anything to the contrary in the Fines Reform Act 2014, any amount recovered in relation to an offence referred to in subsection (1) must be paid into the WorkCover Authority Fund, unless regulations made under the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013 expressly provide otherwise. inserted by No. 32/2006 s. 94(Sch. item 36(1)). inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 19. inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 19. substituted by No. 32/2006 s. 94(Sch. item 36(2)). repealed by No. 32/2006 s. 94(Sch. item 36(3)), new s. 139(4) inserted by No. 10/2022 s. 53.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s143.title: Imputing conduct to bodies corporate
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s143.content:
For the purposes of this Act and the regulations, 
any conduct engaged in on behalf of a body 
corporate by an employee, agent or officer 
(within the meaning given by section 9 of the 
Corporations Act) of the body corporate acting 
within the actual or apparent scope of his or her 
employment, or within his or her actual or 
apparent authority, is conduct also engaged in by 
the body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s144.title: Liability of officers of bodies corporate

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s144/1.content: If a body corporate (including a body corporate representing the Crown) contravenes a provision of this Act or the regulations and the contravention is attributable to an officer of the body corporate failing to take reasonable care, the officer is guilty of an offence and liable to—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s144/1/a.content: if the provision contravened was section 39G(1), a fine not exceeding 10 000 penalty units; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s144/1/b.content: otherwise, a fine not exceeding the maximum fine for an offence constituted by a contravention by a natural person of the provision contravened by the body corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s144/2.content: An offence against subsection (1) is summary or indictable in nature according to whether the offence constituted by the contravention by the body corporate is summary or indictable. Ss 140–142 repealed by No. 32/2006 s. 94(Sch. item 36(3)). amended by No. 50/2019 s. 6.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s144/3.content: In determining whether an officer of a body Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 154 corporate is guilty of an offence, regard must be had to—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s144/3/a.content: what the officer knew about the matter concerned; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s144/3/b.content: the extent of the officer's ability to make, or participate in the making of, decisions that affect the body corporate in relation to the matter concerned; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s144/3/c.content: whether the contravention by the body corporate is also attributable to an act or omission of any other person; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s144/4.content: An officer of a body corporate may be convicted or found guilty of an offence in accordance with subsection (1) whether or not the body corporate has been convicted or found guilty of the offence committed by it.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s144/5.content: An officer of a body corporate (including a body corporate representing the Crown) who is a volunteer is not liable to be prosecuted under this section for anything done or not done by him or her as a volunteer. Notes 1 Officer of a body corporate includes a person who makes or participates in the making of decisions that affect the whole or a substantial part of the body corporate's business and a person who has the capacity to affect significantly the body corporate's financial standing (see section 5). 2 For volunteer, see section 5.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145.title: Liability of officers of partnerships and
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
156   
 (a) what the officer knew about the matter 
concerned; and 
 (b) the extent of the officer's ability to make, or 
participate in the making of, decisions that 
affect the partnership, body or association in 
relation to the matter concerned; and 
 (c) whether the commission of the offence is 
also attributable to an act or omission of any 
other person; and 
 (d) any other relevant matter. 
 (5) An officer of a partnership or unincorporated body 
or association who is a volunteer is not liable to be 
prosecuted under this section for anything done or 
not done by him or her as a volunteer. 
Notes 
1 Officer of a partnership or unincorporated body or 
association includes a person who makes or 
participates in the making of decisions that affect the 
whole or a substantial part of the business of the 
partnership, body or association and a person who has 
the capacity to affect significantly the financial 
standing of the partnership, body or association 
(see section 5). 
2 For volunteer, see section 5.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/1.content: Subject to subsection (2), if— Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 155

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/1/a.content: this Act or the regulations imposes a duty on a person or provides that a person is guilty of an offence; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/1/b.content: the person is a partnership or an unincorporated body or association (including a partnership or an unincorporated body or association representing the Crown)— the reference to the person is taken to be instead a reference to each officer of the partnership, body or association (as the case may be).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/2.content: If an offence against this Act or the regulations is committed by an officer of a partnership or an unincorporated body or association because of the effect of subsection (1), the officer is only guilty of the offence if the commission of the offence is attributable to the officer failing to take reasonable care.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/3.content: The penalty to which an officer of a partnership or an unincorporated body or association is liable for an offence committed by the officer because of the effect of subsection (1) is—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/3/a.content: if the offence is against section 39G(1), a fine not exceeding 10 000 penalty units; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/3/b.content: otherwise, a fine not exceeding the maximum fine that could be imposed by a court on a natural person found guilty of the same offence committed at the same time (otherwise than because of the effect of subsection (1)).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/4.content: In determining whether an officer of a partnership or unincorporated body or association is guilty of an offence, regard must be had to— amended by No. 48/2017 s. 24. amended by No. 48/2017 s. 24. substituted by No. 50/2019 s. 7.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/a.content: what the officer knew about the matter Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 156 concerned; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/b.content: the extent of the officer's ability to make, or participate in the making of, decisions that affect the partnership, body or association in relation to the matter concerned; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/c.content: whether the commission of the offence is also attributable to an act or omission of any other person; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s145/5.content: An officer of a partnership or unincorporated body or association who is a volunteer is not liable to be prosecuted under this section for anything done or not done by him or her as a volunteer. Notes 1 Officer of a partnership or unincorporated body or association includes a person who makes or participates in the making of decisions that affect the whole or a substantial part of the business of the partnership, body or association and a person who has the capacity to affect significantly the financial standing of the partnership, body or association (see section 5). 2 For volunteer, see section 5.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s146.title: Responsible agency for the Crown
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s146.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
157   
 (a) whose acts or omissions are alleged to 
constitute the offence; or 
 (b) if that agency has ceased to exist, that is the 
successor of that agency; or 
 (c) if that agency has ceased to exist and there is 
no clear successor, that the court declares to 
be the responsible agency. 
 (3) The responsible agency in respect of an offence is 
entitled to act in proceedings against the Crown 
for the offence and, subject to any relevant rules 
of court, the procedural rights and obligations of 
the Crown as the accused in the proceedings are 
conferred or imposed on the responsible agency. 
 (4) The person prosecuting the offence may change 
the responsible agency during the proceedings 
with the court's leave.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s146/1.content: If the Crown is to be served with an infringement notice, or proceedings are brought against the Crown, for an offence against this Act or the regulations the responsible agency in respect of the offence may be specified in the infringement notice or any document initiating, or relating to, the proceedings (as the case may be).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s146/2.content: In this section, the responsible agency in respect of an offence is the agency of the Crown—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s146/a.content: whose acts or omissions are alleged to Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 157 constitute the offence; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s146/b.content: if that agency has ceased to exist, that is the successor of that agency; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s146/c.content: if that agency has ceased to exist and there is no clear successor, that the court declares to be the responsible agency.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s146/3.content: The responsible agency in respect of an offence is entitled to act in proceedings against the Crown for the offence and, subject to any relevant rules of court, the procedural rights and obligations of the Crown as the accused in the proceedings are conferred or imposed on the responsible agency.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s146/4.content: The person prosecuting the offence may change the responsible agency during the proceedings with the court's leave.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s147.title: Infringement and other notices may be issued to the
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s147.content:
Crown 
 (1) The Crown in any capacity may be issued with an 
infringement notice for an offence against this Act 
or the regulations. 
Note 
For infringement notices generally, see Division 3. 
 (2) If a notice is to be issued to the Crown under 
Division 5 of Part 7 or Division 8 of Part 9 by a 
health and safety representative or inspector, the 
notice may be issued to the agency of the Crown 
that would be the responsible agency under 
section 146 if the Crown were prosecuted for an 
offence of contravening the notice.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s147/1.content: The Crown in any capacity may be issued with an Crown infringement notice for an offence against this Act or the regulations. Note For infringement notices generally, see Division 3.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s147/2.content: If a notice is to be issued to the Crown under Division 5 of Part 7 or Division 8 of Part 9 by a health and safety representative or inspector, the notice may be issued to the agency of the Crown that would be the responsible agency under section 146 if the Crown were prosecuted for an offence of contravening the notice.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148.title: Proceedings against successors to public bodies

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148/1.content: In this section, public body means—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148/1/a.content: a body corporate representing the Crown; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148/b.content: a State owned enterprise or reorganising Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 158 body (within the meaning of the State Owned Enterprises Act 1992); or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148/c.content: a Council (within the meaning of the Local Government Act 2020); or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148/d.content: a public entity (within the meaning of the Public Administration Act 2004).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148/2.content: Proceedings for an offence against this Act or the regulations that were instituted against a public body before its dissolution, or that could have been instituted against a public body if not for its dissolution, may be continued or instituted against its successor if the successor is a public body.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148/3.content: An infringement notice served on a public body for an offence against this Act or the regulations is taken to be an infringement notice served on its successor if the successor is a public body.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148/4.content: Similarly, any penalty paid by a public body in respect of an infringement notice is taken to be a penalty paid by its successor if the successor is a public body. amended by No. 9/2020 s. 390(Sch. 1 item 74).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148A.title: Certain insurance and indemnity arrangements void
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148A.content:
A term of a contract or other arrangement that 
purports to insure or indemnify a person for the 
person's liability to pay a pecuniary penalty under 
this Act or the regulations is void to the extent that 
the term provides for that insurance or indemnity.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148B.title: Prohibition on insurance and indemnity for
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148B.content:
pecuniary penalties 
 (1) A person must not— 
 (a) enter into or be a party to a contract or other 
arrangement that purports to insure or 
indemnify the person for the person's 
liability to pay a pecuniary penalty under this 
Act or the regulations; or 
 (b) enter into, offer to enter into or be a party to 
a contract or other arrangement that purports 
to insure or indemnify another person for 
that other person's liability to pay a 
pecuniary penalty under this Act or the 
regulations.  
Penalty: 300 penalty units for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148B/1.content: A person must not— pecuniary penalties

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148B/1/a.content: enter into or be a party to a contract or other arrangement that purports to insure or indemnify the person for the person's liability to pay a pecuniary penalty under this Act or the regulations; or

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s148B/1/b.content: enter into, offer to enter into or be a party to a contract or other arrangement that purports to insure or indemnify another person for that other person's liability to pay a pecuniary penalty under this Act or the regulations. Penalty: 300 penalty units for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1500.title: penalty units for a body corporate.
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1500.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
161

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1500/2.content: A person does not commit an offence against subsection (1) if the person has a reasonable excuse for entering into, offering to enter into or being a party to the contract or other arrangement. Pt 11A (Heading and s. 148A) inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 7. inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 7. inserted by No. 36/2021 s. 8.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1500/3.content: A person must not receive a benefit under a term Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 160 of a contract or other arrangement that is a term which purports to insure or indemnify the person for the person's liability for a pecuniary penalty under this Act or the regulations. Penalty: 300 penalty units for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1500/4.content: A person must not provide a benefit to another person under a term of a contract or other arrangement that is a term which purports to insure or indemnify that other person for that person's liability for a pecuniary penalty under this Act or the regulations. Penalty: 300 penalty units for a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s1500/5.content: An offence against subsection (1), (3) or (4) is an indictable offence. Note However, the offence may be heard and determined summarily (see section 28 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2009).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s149.title: Compliance codes
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s149.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
162   
 (6) The Minister must ensure that a copy of— 
 (a) each compliance code that is currently 
approved; and 
 (b) each document applied, adopted or 
incorporated (to any extent) by a compliance 
code— 
is available for inspection by members of the 
public without charge at the office of the 
Authority during normal business hours.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s149/1.content: For the purpose of providing practical guidance to persons who have duties or obligations under this Act or the regulations, the Minister may make an order approving a compliance code.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s149/2.content: A compliance code may apply, adopt or incorporate any matter contained in a document formulated, issued or published by a person or body whether—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s149/2/b.content: as in force at a particular time or from time to time.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s149/3.content: The Minister may make an order approving the variation of a compliance code or revoking the approval of a compliance code.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s149/4.content: An order approving a compliance code, or a variation or revocation order, takes effect when notice of it is published in the Government Gazette or on such later date as is specified in the order. Note The Minister's power to make an order approving a compliance code, or a variation order, is subject to disallowance by the Parliament (see section 151).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s149/5.content: As soon as practicable after making an order approving a compliance code, or a variation or revocation order, the Minister must ensure that notice of the making of the order is published in the Government Gazette and a newspaper circulating generally throughout the State.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s149/6.content: The Minister must ensure that a copy of— Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 162

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s149/6/a.content: each compliance code that is currently approved; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s149/6/b.content: each document applied, adopted or incorporated (to any extent) by a compliance code— is available for inspection by members of the public without charge at the office of the Authority during normal business hours.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s150.title: Effect of compliance codes
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s150.content:
A failure to comply with a compliance code does 
not give rise to any civil or criminal liability. 
Note 
A person who complies with a compliance code may, 
however, be taken to have complied with this Act 
(see section 152).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151.title: Disallowance of certain compliance code orders
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
163

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151/1.content: The Minister's power to make an order approving a compliance code, or a variation order, under section 149 is subject to the order being disallowed by the Parliament.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151/2.content: Section 15 and Part 5 of the Subordinate Legislation Act 1994 apply for the purposes of subsection (1) as though—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151/2/a.content: an order were a statutory rule (within the meaning of that Act); and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151/2/b.content: notice of the making of the statutory rule had been published in the Government Gazette when notice of the order or variation order (as the case may be) was published in the Government Gazette.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A.title: Contributions by non-WorkCover employers to the
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A.content:
Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 
No. 107 of 2004 
167

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/1.content: The Authority must determine the amount of WorkCover Authority Fund contributions payable into the WorkCover Authority Fund under section 513 of the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013 by non-WorkCover employers to be applied towards the costs and expenses incurred by the Authority for the provision of occupational health, safety and welfare regulation and related education and prevention services.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/2.content: The amount is to be determined in accordance with the formula— ( ) G ]FED[CB A ++− — where— "A" is the rateable remuneration paid or payable by the non-WorkCover employer during the preceding financial year calculated as if the non-WorkCover employer were an employer liable to pay a premium under the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013; "B" is the sum of the total rateable remuneration paid or payable— (i) by all employers liable to pay a premium under the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013 during the preceding financial year; and inserted by No. 28/2005 s. 29. amended by No. 67/2013 s. 649(Sch. 9 item 25(7)(a)). amended by No. 67/2013 s. 649 (Sch. 9 item 25(7)(b)–(e)).

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/3.content: The costs referred to in "E" in subsection (2) are Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 165 "E" is, subject to any adjustment in accordance with subsection (3), the sum of the costs incurred by the Authority in the preceding quarter related to— (i) the operation and management of its rehabilitation, compensation and insurance functions; (ii) the administration, operation, management and maintenance of the Authority's central computer network used by authorised agents; (iii) actuarial services provided to the Authority; (iv) the administration and support of the operation and management of its rehabilitation, compensation and insurance functions (other than costs referred to in subparagraphs (ii) and (iii)); "F" is the sum of the costs, including the administration costs, incurred by the Authority in the preceding quarter directly related to the administration and support of public safety activities and operations; "G" is 60% or, if another percentage, not exceeding 100%, is prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this section, the prescribed percentage. to be assessed for each quarter and, following the annual audit of the Authority's financial statements, any necessary adjustments made to the total of "E" in the next quarterly contribution payable.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/4.content: The contribution by a non-WorkCover Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 No. 107 of 2004 166 employer—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/4/a.content: is payable on 1 August, 1 November, 1 February and 1 May in each year; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/4/b.content: must be paid within 14 days of the due date.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/5.content: If a contribution is not paid by the due date, the amount of the contribution together with interest at the prescribed rate and a surcharge of $100 per day until the contribution is paid may be recovered by the Authority as a civil debt recoverable summarily.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/6.content: A non-WorkCover employer must at the intervals specified by the Authority submit to the Authority—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/6/a.content: a return in the form approved by the Authority; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/6/b.content: a statutory declaration in support of the information provided in the return— to enable the Authority to determine the amount of contributions payable.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/7.content: A non-WorkCover employer who fails to comply with subsection (6) is guilty of an offence against this Act and liable to a penalty for each day during which the default continues of—

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/7/a.content: 1 penalty unit in the case of a natural person;

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s151A/7/b.content: 5 penalty units in the case of a body corporate.

under subsection (1).

corporate.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s152.title: Effect of compliance with regulations or compliance
/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s152.content:
codes 
If— 
 (a) the regulations or a compliance code make 
provision for or with respect to a duty or 
obligation imposed by this Act or the 
regulations; and 
 (b) a person complies with the regulations or 
compliance code to the extent that it makes 
that provision— 
the person is, for the purposes of this Act and the 
regulations, taken to have complied with this Act 
or the regulations in relation to that duty or 
obligation.

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s152/a.content: the regulations or a compliance code make codes If— provision for or with respect to a duty or obligation imposed by this Act or the regulations; and

/au-victoria/ohs/2004/s152/b.content: a person complies with the regulations or compliance code to the extent that it makes that provision— the person is, for the purposes of this Act and the regulations, taken to have complied with this Act or the regulations in relation to that duty or obligation.
